story: Princess Eugenie and fiance Jack will marry at Windsor Castle (Image: getty)Princess Eugenie and fiance Jack Brooksbank like the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, Earl of Wessex and the Queen's eldest grandson Peter Phillips will get married in St George's Chapel on Friday October 12.Even the Prince of Wales wed in Windsor the second time around - in a civil ceremony in the town's Guildhall, followed by a blessing in St George's.Here's a look at some of the Windsor royal weddings:- Prince Harry &amp Meghan Markle                Princess Eugenie's wedding dress CLUE: Royal slips MAJOR detail on ...                Princess Eugenie Royal Wedding: Queen to wear blue hat - bookies oddsHarry and Meghan's St George's chapel wedding on May 19 was the royal event of 2018.The US-born former Suits star wore a simple but elegant gown by Clare Waight Keller and a five metre-long veil, held in place by Queen Mary's diamond bandeau tiara, which featured flowers from all Commonwealth countries.Just a few days before the wedding Meghan's father announced he would not be giving his daughter away due to health reasons, but Charles stepped in to perform the symbolic role.Harry was given the title of the Duke of Sussex on his wedding day and his wife became the Duchess of Sussex.Thousands lined the streets of Windsor to watch the newlyweds when they went on a carriage procession through the town and the Long Walk in Windsor Great Park.The evening celebrations were staged in nearby Frogmore House where close family and friends partied the night away.Harry drove his wife to the event in a classic British sports car - an electric E-type Jaguar.- The Prince of Wales &amp Camilla Parker Bowles                Sarah Ferguson and Prince Philip bury the hatchet at Eugenie's wedding                Sarah Ferguson embrace by the Queen ahead of Princess Eugenie wedding Charles finally married his former mistress Camilla Parker Bowles in 2005 after a relationship which ned decades.The ceremony was due to take place in Windsor Castle, but they were forced to switch venues to the more modest local town hall around the corner.It emerged that licensing the castle would have allowed the public to marry there too and the publicly announced original plan was hastily dropped.In the end, Charles and Camilla wed in a private, civil ceremony in Windsor's Guildhall in front of just 30 guests.Clarence House official handout photo of the Prince of Wales and his new bride Camilla (Image: getty)But the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh were not present.The monarch's position as Head of the Church of England made it difficult for her to attend a non-religious wedding.However, she did join the 800 guests who witnessed Charles and Camilla's televised, religious blessing afterwards in St George's Chapel.Camilla, who became an HRH and the Duchess of Cornwall on marriage, wore an oyster silk basket-weave dress and coat for her civil wedding and a porcelain blue silk coat and gold sweeping feathered head-dress for the blessing.Both outfits were by Robinson Valentine.The newylweds posed for photographs with the royal family afterwards on the vast west steps of St George's, just as Eugenie and Jack are certain to do.There was no carriage procession for Charles and Camilla because of sensitivity surrounding the public's reaction and the nation's affection for Charles's first wife, the late Diana, Princess of Wales.- Peter Phillips &amp Autumn KellyPeter Phillips - son of the Princess Royal - married Canadian Autumn Kelly in 2008 at St George's Chapel.Peter Phillips marries Autumn Kelly at St. George's Chapel on May 17, 2008 (Image: getty)The bride wore a gown by Sassi Holford and a tiara borrowed from her new mother-in-law, the Princess Royal.Peter's sister Zara raised eyebrows when her strapless bridesmaid's dress showed off her distinctive tan lines.Peter and Autumn left in a horse-drawn Balmoral Sociable carriage for a reception and dance at Frogmore House.- Prince Edward &amp Sophie Rhys-JonesIn 1999, Prince Edward married Sophie Rhys-Jones in St George's Chapel.Edward was given the title the Earl of Wessex on the morning of his wedding and Sophie became the Countess of Wessex on marriage.Sophie's dress by Samantha Shaw was a V-neck, hand-dyed silk organza and silk crepe design, embellished with 325,000 pearls and crystal beads and teamed with a spotted crystal detail veil.The wedding began at 5pm and men were asked to wear morning dress, but women evening dress without hats, to the continental-style evening service.Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys-Jones with their bridesmaid and pageboy (Image: getty)There was no public kiss at the televised nuptials for Edward and Sophie, whose first kiss as a married couple took place in the privacy of the Chapel's ambulatory, where they signed the marriage register.The reception afterwards was held in the state apartments of Windsor Castle.Unlike Harry's wedding, there was no military involvement. But the couple did enjoy a carriage procession through the town.- Other Windsor royal weddingsLady Helen Windsor, the daughter of the Queen's cousin the Duke of Kent, married Timothy Taylor at St George's Chapel in 1992.There was a big royal turnout and seven-year-old Prince Harry, smartly dressed in a double-breasted blazer and tie, was a guest.Historic weddings in Windsor have included the nuptials of King Edward VII, who as the Prince of Wales married Princess Alexandra of Denmark in St George's on March 10 1863.His mother Queen Victoria was a guest.Many of Victoria's children chose to be married at Windsor, particularly during the Queen's reclusive widowhood.

title: brexit news irish border dr ray bassett northern ireland hard border
story: Dr Ray Bassett warned Dublin it must start looking out for Ireland&rsquos own interests rather than attempting to score points with Brussels by toeing the EU&rsquos line over the frontier.The former ambassador acknowledged that no technological solution which can completely avoid the need for border infrastructure currently exists, but insisted &ldquogoodwill and common sense between the neighbouring nations &ldquoshould allow for a workable solution.And he urged Leo Varadkar&rsquos government to come to its senses and &ldquorealise that its deep connections with its neighbour, the United Kingdom, are more valuable than temporary plaudits from Brussels.The issue of how to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic has become the last major hurdle negotiators need to overcome to secure a Brexit deal.                Arlene Foster applauds Theresa May for 'STANDING FIRM' against EUBrussels has put forward two options but Theresa May has rejected both, warning the first would effectively cut Northern Ireland off from the rest of the UK and the other would &ldquomake a mockery of the decision to leave the EU.The Prime Minister warned last week that if the bloc is not willing to budge in its demands and agree on a compromise, Britain could leave with no deal.But Dr Bassett said &ldquothere is no need for the Irish border question either to derail the EUUK Brexit discussions or to determine the overall agreement.And he insisted a solution has not been reached purely because of political, not practical reasons.Brexit news: The Irish border issue is political, not practical, Dr Ray Bassett said (Image:  IMAGES)Dr Bassett worked for Ireland's Department of Foreign Affairs for 39 years (Image: NC)Irish leader Leo Varadkar needs to put Ireland's interests first, Dr Bassett said (Image: PA)                Brexit news: Irish border could be solved with THIS tech says expertIn a new paper on the Irish border question published by the Politeia think-tank, Dr Bassett said: &ldquoThe border question has been used by elements within the Remain camp to try and block the UK&rsquos departure from the EU.&ldquoIt is certainly not in the long-term interest of Ireland to be used in this cynical manner.&ldquoWhile there is no comparable international example that can be readily used to solve the issue, goodwill and common sense should allow for a workable solution.&ldquoIt could be based on major exemptions for small companies and purely local trade, as well as agricultural and food products. The remaining trade could be monitored and operated on a trusted trader system.&ldquoUnder these arrangements, there would be no need for any new physical infrastructure on the border.&ldquoThe danger is that politics, not practicalities, will get in the way.Remain supporters in Northern Ireland are staunchly opposed to a hard border (Image:  IMAGES)Dr Bassett served in Ireland&rsquos Department of Foreign Affairs for 39 years during which time he was involved in the Good Friday Agreement negotiations.He has since become an outspoken critic of the Irish government&rsquos approach to Brexit.Dr Bassett said an exit deal which allows for frictionless trade between the UK and Ireland is &ldquovital for Irish interests.He said half of Ireland&rsquos beef is purchased by Britain with firms in the UK also buying between 40 and 50 percent of exports from Irish small and medium-sized businesses.Theresa May has rejected the EU's options for the Irish border (Image:  IMAGES)He said: &ldquoHence, it is overwhelmingly in Ireland&rsquos interest that the UK and the EU agree to friction-free arrangements across a wide range of areas.&ldquoRationally, Ireland should be the UK&rsquos strongest ally inside the EU, pressing for the best possible terms and a successful Brexit.The former diplomat also questioned Ireland&rsquos &ldquoslavish devotion to the EU.He predicted his home country will see a &ldquogrowing disenchantment with Brussels as the bloc attempts to move towards a &ldquoUnited States of Europe.He added: &ldquoThe whole sustainability of the European Union, as presently constituted, is in serious long-term doubt.&ldquoIreland needs to be on the right side of these historical developments.

title: Brexit news UK Labour Party Jeremy Corbyn Keir Starmer Kate Hoey Hilary Benn EU
story: Jeremy Corbyn said at the Labour Party conference in Liverpool this week that MPs would vote down any Chequers based Brexit plan and called for the Prime Minister to change her blueprint if she wanted support from Labour.Theresa May has claimed negotiations are at an &ldquoimpasse and is defiantly standing by her controversial Chequers plan which has received criticism from within her party, and from EU leaders at Salzburg.At the conference in Liverpool, Labour Party frontbenchers insisted that they wanted a general election instead of a second Brexit vote, but added all options were still &ldquoon the table should Mrs May&rsquos plan not get through the House of Commons.Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer said &ldquonobody is ruling out Remain as an option should there be another referendum on Britain&rsquos relationship with the EU, and claimed Labour would only back a deal that met all of the party&rsquos six tests.                Labour's Caroline Flint RIPS into colleagues backing People's Vote                Councillor mocks attempted Remain 'TAKEOVER' for new Brexit voteSpeaking exclusively with Express, Labour Party MP for Don Valley, Caroline Flint clearly outlined why the party could not back another referendum on leaving the EU.She said: &ldquoWe did have a people&rsquos vote in 2016, and I don&rsquot feel any sense that people have changed their minds. They want us to get on with it. The problem with a second referendum is that it will just reopen, I think, all the isions that emerged in 2016.&ldquoWhat I want to see is a reasonable deal that allows us to get on with things, but also concentrate on some of those massive issues that people had around the country where they voted Leave.&ldquoCommunities like Doncaster and&nbspelsewhere&nbspdidn&rsquot feel they were getting a better share of the national wealth that they were entitled to. In all this debate, that isn&rsquot being discussed as much as it should be.Speaking alongside Ms Flint at a fringe meeting on Tuesday evening, Labour peer Lord Adonis described himself as a &ldquohardline&nbspRemainer and a &ldquodemocrat before calling for a People&rsquos Vote.He said: &ldquoThe people cannot betray the people - let&rsquos understand this. The idea the answer to a problem of democracy is no more democracy - we don&rsquot do that with elections. When we lose an election we don&rsquot say, &lsquooh well we are not having any more of those, we lost that, we are giving up&rsquo. What we do is we carry on arguing.Leading Brexit supporter and Labour MP for Vauxhall, Kate Hoey, was adamant that pro-Remain MPs in the Labour Party were &ldquonot going to get a People&rsquos Vote at the end of Brexit negotiations with the European Union.Ms Hoey also warned that it would be nearly impossible for there to be another general election, which Labour frontbenchers were demanding. She said: &ldquoIt&rsquos going to be very difficult to have a general election, even if nobody wants any deal the Prime Minister brings back with, because of the fixed term parliament.&ldquoI think a lot of MPs who might say publicly they might like a general election, but actually, in&nbsppractice&nbspdo they really want it, on both sides?&ldquoThe electorate at the moment is very volatile and no-one can take for granted&nbspthe electorate's vote&nbspand how they are going to vote no matter what they did in the past.Brexit news: Labour MP's discussed whether there should be a People's Vote at conference (Image: EXPRESS&bull)British entrepreneur John Mills commented on whether the People&rsquos Vote was picking up &ldquomomentum. Mr Mills claimed support was rising, but only in London and Canterbury, and not in&nbspWales, the Midlands and the north of England.He said: &ldquoI think for the Labour Party to start supporting having a second referendum is&nbspa very&nbspdangerous course of action and I think the leadership of the Labour Party realise this.Chair of the Brexit select committee, Hilary Benn, admitted that it was &ldquohard to see a majority of MPs coming out to back&nbspa second&nbspvote.He said: &ldquoI don&rsquot know, I think at the moment it&rsquos hard to see a majority for that emerging in the House of Commons. We&rsquove got a long way to go in this process, ironically in a short amount of time.He added: &ldquoI think the best way to get a sensible Brexit negotiated is to have a change of Government. Because if the Prime Minister has boxed herself in and has nowhere to go now&hellipwe would have a very different kind of Brexit if a Labour Government was elected.The prospect of a change of leadership was echoed by Labour&rsquos shadow justice secretary Richard Burgon who said a general election is a real possibility.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos not in Labour&rsquos gift to call for a general election but I think a general election is a real possibility and that&rsquos our preference. If a Labour Government is elected in that early general election then what we&rsquoll do is bring the country together.&ldquoAccept and respect the referendum and secure a Brexit that meets the six tests that Keir Starmer has set out.Labour&rsquos shadow communities and local government secretary, Andrew Gwynne, added that Labour did not want to &ldquoreopen the 2016 referendum result as he called for a general election.Mr Gwynne also claimed the Government had &ldquofailed miserably in negotiations with the EU.The Mayor of Greater Manchester, Andy Burnham made clear the Brexit result must be &ldquorespected, claiming that the best outcome would be a &ldquodeal.Mr Burnham added that there could only be a People&rsquos Vote if &ldquofurther down the line a no deal is looking like a possible scenario and would only be acceptable as a &ldquolast resort.However, Labour MP for Exeter Ben Bradshaw claimed that &ldquopeople&rsquos minds are changing as they see the reality of Brexit &ndash particularly the reality of the prospect of a no deal Brexit.He added: &ldquoThe Government has completely failed to deliver Brexit in a competent way and we are facing the prospect of either a very bad deal or no deal at all which would be catastrophic for our economy.Labour MP Caroline Flint explained why the party should not back a People's Vote (Image: EXPRESS)&ldquoAnd I think in those circumstances, parliamentarians, whatever their political colour, are going to do what they know is in the best interests of their constituents. If the prospect of the choice is between a crash out no deal scenario and another referendum, I think that&rsquos what they would go for.Labour MP for Blackley and Broughton, Graham Stringer, said he did not think there was a majority in the House of Commons for a second referendum on leaving the EU.Mr Stringer said the arguments of those calling for a second referendum did not &ldquostack up. He said: &ldquoI don&rsquot think there will be a second referendum, nor should there be.Ronnie Campbell, Labour MP for Blyth Valley, added that the Labour Party needed to be &ldquovery careful about&nbspa second&nbspvote on Europe.He said: &ldquoIf they are saying it is a vote for a no deal, that might be a different matter, because a no deal, we don&rsquot know what a no deal could look like, we could go off an oblivion.&ldquoBut, not on Europe. We have had that referendum. We are leaving Europe. We have got to leave on the best terms possible. And if the Tories can&rsquot do it, there is a Labour Government there waiting to be in.Kent Labour Councillor Brendan Chilton claimed that Leave would win any future Brexit vote by a bigger majority but warned the party about &ldquoalienating working-class voters from the Labour Party.Prominent Labour politicians have joined calls for a People&rsquos Vote after Brexit negotiations, including the London Mayor Sadiq Khan.Addressing the conference on Wednesday, Mr Corbyn insisted Labour would not overturn Brexit but questioned the conduct of the May Government during the negotiations with Brussels.Mr Corbyn said: &ldquoLabour respects the decision of the British people in the referendum but no one can respect the conduct of the government since that vote took place.As it stands, Labour will vote against the Chequers plan or whatever is left of it and oppose leaving the EU with no deal. And it is inconceivable that we should crash out of Europe with no deal &ndash that would be a national disaster.&ldquoThat is why if Parliament votes down a Tory deal or the government fails to reach any deal at all we would press for a general election. Failing that, all options are on the table. Brexit is about the future of our country and our vital interests.Additional reporting by Jodie Packwood in Liverpool.

title: brexit news eu cfp common fisheries policy uk fishermen
story: Policies imposed by Brussels on British fishermen have hugely harmed traditional fishing operations, experts from the University of Kent said.In their paper, researchers from the Kent&rsquos School of Anthropology and Conservation (SAC) stated the EU policies are favouring larger boats and richer owners.As a result, smaller fleets and iniduals were pushed out of their livelihood.Professor Douglas MacMillan, one of the researchers taking part in the study, said the CFP focuses too much on fish stock conservation and has no meaningful policy regulations to ensure that quotas for over-fished stock such as tuna are equally shared amongst fishermen.&nbsp                Brexiteer trashes Remainer's claim fishermen won't benefit from Brexit                Brexiteer Fisherman lists these KEY reasons for Brexit Nick Harvey, a spokesman for Seafarers UKHe said: &ldquoThis allows inidual nations to implement their own policies, which more often than not are captured by local elites to enhance their wealth and power through, for example, capturing all the quota.&ldquoFurthermore, additional conservation measures such as no-fishing zones are crude and tend to curtail all fishing activity over large segments of coastal waters, regardless of whether the fishing undertaken there is sustainable or not.Seafarers UK, a British charity helping people in the maritime community, agrees the CFP&rsquos limitations on quota harm fishermen.Nick Harvey, a spokesman for Seafarers UK, told Express: &ldquoSeafarers UK&rsquos research found that in smaller UK ports, real challenges exist for some fishermen because of the limited access to quota.&nbspThe EU's Common Fisheries Policy is threatening the survival of British fishermen, a study said (Image: )Seafarers UK&rsquos recent research reported that accidents at sea were commonplace (Image: )&ldquoThese limitations restrict earning potential, which can impact on an inidual&rsquos personal and financial circumstances.Seafarers UK also highlighted that the same fishermen living in financial difficulties risk their lives at sea every day.Calling upon the Government in a bid to ensure fishermen&rsquos lives are protected as well as their catch, Mr Harvey said: &ldquoSeafarers UK is concerned that too much emphasis is being placed on fish quotas and more must be done to ensure the health, safety and welfare of UK fishermen who risk their lives to put food on Britain&rsquos tables.&ldquoSeafarers UK&rsquos recent research reported that accidents at sea were commonplace, with many having experienced capsized and sinking vessels as well as falling overboard.&nbsp&nbsp&ldquoOver a third reported injuries received as a result of accidents.&nbsp&nbsp                May blasts Labour and SNP over support to EU bid to control UK fishing&ldquoOthers reported an impact on their health as a result of their working conditions.The CFP has also affected also other areas of the bloc.Dr Alicia Said, another researcher at the University of Kent, comes from a traditional Maltese fishing community and has experienced first-hand the effects of EU policies.She said: &ldquoIn Malta, the small traditional fishermen have essentially been pushed out of the water and their livelihood by government and EU policies that were actually intended to conserve fish stocks.&ldquoAt the end of the day the small guy ends up with nothing but a meagre retirement package, fishing communities fall into a spiral of decay, and profits for the large boat owners soar as they can capture all the quota and use cheap, often illegal labour to catch the fish.&nbsp&nbsp

title: brexit no deal theresa may meat shortage
story: Bidfood needs assurances before Christmas otherwise it will have no choice but to stockpile food (Image: )Bidfood UK is holding crunch talks with customers fearing links to its European producers could be severely impacted if Britain leaves the EU without a deal.It needs assurances before Christmas otherwise it will have no choice but to stockpile food.Two-thirds of Bidfood UK&rsquos 15,000 food items are sourced in the UK but Bidfood UK chief executive Andrew Selley said a hard Brexit would mean shortages of EU products including chips from Belgium, pasta and olive oil from Italy and meat from eastern Europe.Mr Selley said: &ldquoWe&rsquore looking at where we could switch to different products that are UK sourced.                Brexiteer brands Labour MP 'RIDICULOUS' over no deal stockpiling claim                'There is no better Brexit!' Patrick Kielty blasts Boris Johnson plan&ldquoIn a partnership approach with customers, we&rsquore working on menu development, to say: &lsquoThis product may not be available. A lot of meat products like chicken in the UK come from Holland an Poland, so could you look at more non-meat products, vegan or vegetarian options?&rsquo.Bidfood UK uses 1,000 trucks to make 12,000 deliveries from 24,000 depots week.The firm is one of a growing number that fear a collapse of the pound could end up pushing their costs up higher.Many similar companies also fear they could face a shortage of EU workers in the event of a hard Brexit and delays at British ports could hold up deliveries and ruin stock.Mr Selley said unless there was a breakthrough before Christmas, his firm would be forced to ship in extra supplies.He said: &ldquoWe&rsquod need safety stocks in for some of those items if we felt it was going to be a hard Brexit and we felt those border delays would happen.A survey this week by the Chartered Institute of Procurement and Supply said just one in 10 UK firms fear bankruptcy as a result of as a result of a no-deal Brexit that would result in port delays by even just one hour.Today, an MP warned Theresa May&rsquos premiership could be in trouble after former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson released his own six-point Brexit plan yesterday, which had emerged after the failure of her own Chequers plan when presented to Brussels.                Tory Brexiteer claims overturning Brexit would be like 'LOSING A WAR'Brexiteer MP Bernard Jenkin said: &ldquo&ldquoThe problem for the Prime Minister is that she has hitched herself to the wrong policy.&rsquoHe then blasted the Government for &ldquoswallowing Project Fear.He also said that although he would &ldquonever underestimate Mrs May, he blasted &ldquoweakly conducted negotiations and said that &ldquothe Government has never really accepted that we are going to leave the EU.The Brexit talks are currently at an impasse with the issue of how to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic still a major hurdle which has yet to be overcome.Mrs May has insisted her Chequers proposals are the only viable plans, but Brussels last week rejected her plans for the Irish frontier.

title: conwy binn recycling bin collection conway county council wales news
story: An earlier trial of the proposal triggered a 14 percent increase in recycling (Image: )Conwy County Council in north Wales scrapped their initial plan to cut landfill collections to once every three weeks, which had got residents fuming when it was put into place in 2016.They have now replaced the plan with a new one that will see bin men whip around the small market town and rural areas once every four weeks.An earlier trial of the proposal triggered a 14 percent increase in recycling, which led to the council rolling the plan out this week.Officials believe the cut in bin collections will save them up to &pound400,000 annually and save them &pound600,000 in yearly fines from the Welsh government.                Plaid Cymru leader says he'll use 'EVERY MEAN POSSIBLE' to stop Brexit                'It's Labour's fault' BBC host in SHOCKING remark on Welsh Labour ruleThey also hope the change will increase their recycling rates from 64 percent to 70 percent by 2025.But residents have blasted the plan and have reported an increase in rodents, smells and flies.Tracy Hulme, from Old Colwyn, said she has to get a relative to stand on the contents of her wheelie bins in wellies to make room for more household waste from her four young children, three dogs and two cats.Fellow mum-of-four Frankie Hamlet, of Llysfaen, near Colwyn Bay, said she found a rat in her kitchen cupboard and cited the drop in bin collections as the cause.They also hope the change will increase their recycling rates from 64 percent to 70 percent (Image: )She said: &ldquoMy bin was emptied yesterday and it&rsquos already half full.&ldquoIf there&rsquos rubbish hanging around it&rsquos going to make the situation ten times worse.The council said there was no evidence that the piles of rubbish in Ms Hamlet&rsquos area would have attracted rats.A spokesman added it had received 449 reports of rats in the past 12 months, down from 659 the previous year.                Cancer patient with weeks to live told to pay year&rsquos garden bin bil...                Rising trade in stolen wheelie binsYet reports of fly-tipping rose from 986 in the past 12 months to September 2016 to 1,093 in the following year.The change has been condemned by the Chartered Institute of Environmental Health, who said the lack of bin collections would cause a risk to public health from pests, odours and domestic waste burning.Tony Lewis, Chartered Institute of Environmental Health head of policy, said the change could work &ldquoif people stick to the rules but people don&rsquot stick to the rules.Don Milne, Conwy&rsquos Conservative cabinet member for environment, said cutting collections was &ldquoall about increasing recycling.

title: Brexit news David Davis Theresa May Chequers plan EU negotiations latest
story: David Davis has launched a fresh scathing attack on Theresa May (Image: Getty)The former Brexit Secretary warned the Government&rsquos defeat at the summit was due to Mrs May&rsquos advisers not fully grasping the &ldquopracticalities of the negotiations.This included believing in the EU&rsquos exaggerated claims on the ongoing Northern Ireland issue, which Mr Davis describes as being utterly manageable.Speaking from his home near Hodwen, in Yorkshire, Mr Davis told the  he has always campaigned to respect the 2016 Brexit referendum with a &ldquorobust approach, unlike Downing Street.He said: &ldquoThe tendency on the part of the Whitehall advice, and the No 10 advice in particular, is to say, what&rsquos negotiable, what&rsquos achievable.                Brexit COUNTDOWN: The UK&rsquos three options left if Chequers IS chucked                Brexit no deal could see meat and chips taken OFF menu, says supplier Mr Davis claimed he tried to &ldquostrike out the &ldquonew customs partnership plan three times last year.He said: &ldquoI thought at first it was the Treasury being difficult.&ldquoIt turned out it was No 10.&ldquoThey said we&rsquove got to keep it in for &lsquonegotiability&rsquo reasons.Mr Davis said he has always campaigned to respect the result of the 2016 Brexit referendum (Image: Getty)&ldquoThat&rsquos not the way you design your policies.&ldquoYou design your policies, then sell them, then amend them if you do have to do that but not the other way around.The former Brexit Secretary insisted Downing Street made the same mistake when trying to negotiate Chequers with the EU.Making an analogy with between the EU negotiations and buying a car, he said: &ldquo&lsquoWhat would you like me to pay you?&rsquo is not the right approach to a negotiation.                'She's got months to sort Brexit' Lord Howard warns May                 NO DEAL BREXIT EXPLAINED: What does no-deal Brexit mean for the NHS?Mr Davis said that Mrs May's advisors cannot fully understand the 'practicalities' of moving goods (Image: Getty)&ldquoI massively simplify, but that&rsquos the equivalent.Mr Davis then condemned Mrs May&rsquos advisors, who unlike him never ran a business and therefore cannot fully understand the &ldquopracticalities of moving goods.He said: &ldquoWe&rsquove got civil servants who are patriotic, well-intentioned, very intelligent people, but they&rsquove never run a business like that, and so they tend to accept without enough challenge some of the comments that come back from Brussels.&ldquoQuite a lot of the time there is not as strong a grip on the practicalities as I would like, and that means that when you face an argument like Northern Ireland, they believe things that are simply exaggerations.In an optimistic conclusion, he said: Northern Ireland is an issue, but it&rsquos utterly manageable.

title: Brexit news UK EU Theresa May BBC Andrew Marr Show European Union
story: The Prime Minister demanded the European Union set out any &ldquocounter-proposals to her Chequers agreement to resolve any problems with her Brexit blueprint.Speaking on The Andrew Marr Show, the host pressed the Prime Minister on whether she was prepared to compromise on her controversial plan with the EU.Marr said: &ldquoCan I ask, are you prepared in any substantive way, to alter your plan to get an agreement?Theresa May replied: &ldquoWhat I have said to the European Union is very clear. They have said they have some concerns with the proposals we have put together. Let&rsquos hear what those detailed concerns are.                EU trying to 'RUN DOWN the clock' Davis predicts 'scary few months'&ldquoIf they have counter-proposals, let&rsquos hear what those counter-proposals are. What I am clear is that what we have put forward is in the national interest and we did it because what the European Union was offering us was unacceptable.The BBC host Marr pressed the Prime Minister once again asking whether she would be prepared to &ldquomove on her Chequers agreement.Mrs May replied: &ldquoLet&rsquos hear what the European Union&rsquos concerns are with the Chequers plan.&ldquoAt the heart of the Chequers plan is a free trade deal, a free trade area and frictionless trade.&ldquoI think it&rsquos frictionless trade that ensures we maintain our guarantee to the people of Northern Ireland of no hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland.&ldquoChequers at the moment is the only plan on the table that delivers the Brexit vote, in the way I have set out, and also delivers for the people of Northern Ireland.Marr asked Mrs May once again whether she was prepared to compromise on Chequers.He said: &ldquoThey said at Salzburg fairly clearly what they wanted was more and stronger language on the common rulebook on regulations and so on, going forward. Having listened, are you prepared in any sense to compromise?Mrs May claimed that she wanted the European Union to set out their concerns in &ldquodetail with the Chequers plan.Brexit news: Andrew Marr quizzed the Prime Minister over her Brexit blueprint (Image: BBC)When pressed by the host again, Mrs May said: &ldquoLet&rsquos hear the detail of those concerns is. If they have counter proposals, let&rsquos hear what those counter proposals are.&ldquoThey have said there is much about Chequers they can accept and they want to talk with us. So where they have problems, let&rsquos actually hear them. And it is only then Andrew that you can identify what the issue really&nbspis,&nbspif there are issues that lie behind this.Marr pressed the Prime Minister five times whether she was prepared to compromise on her Chequers plan.The Prime Minister has vowed to stick with her Chequers plan despite criticism within her own party and EU leaders on the agreement.Former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has branded the Chequers agreement as &ldquoderanged and has set out his own &ldquoSuper-Canada agreement.Speaking ahead of the Conservative Party conference, the Prime Minister has urged ministers to get behind her Chequers agreement.She said: &ldquoThe theme of Conservative party conference this year is&nbspopportunity. Two years on from the referendum, we&rsquove made progress in the Brexit negotiations at the same time as improving life for people here at home.But we&rsquore now at a crucial moment. The right deal is close &ndash and with it the opportunity to make life better for ordinary working people.So at this Conference, we will be setting out how we will provide&nbspopportunity&nbspfor all &ndash a stronger, fairer country with real opportunity for people who work hard and do the right thing.Labour Party in BREXIT CHAOS: 'Britons want us to GET ON with it'Brexit deal will be 'EASY' to finalise as EU dont want another problemBREXIT LIVE: &lsquoDeranged and preposterous&rsquo Johnson attacks May&rsquos plan

title: Brexit news UK EU BBC Labour Party Andrew Marr Show Theresa May European Union
story: Deputy leader of the Labour Party Tom Watson clashed with BBC host Andrew Marr after the party&rsquos Brexit strategy was criticised.The BBC host claimed the Labour Party were guilty of &ldquocherry picking with their plan to keep &ldquoall the benefits of the single market post-Brexit.Speaking on The Andrew Marr Show, the host said: &ldquoIf you get that general election, and you win it is still quite unclear what you would then do. Because a lot of what you say about Theresa May is also true of you, particularly, for instance, cherry picking.&ldquoYou say you want all the benefits of the single market and the customs union, but you don&rsquot want to accept the industrial rules, the state aid rules and much else. That is classic cherry picking.                BREXIT LIVE: &lsquoDeranged and preposterous&rsquo Johnson attacks May&rsquos plan                Marr quizzes May over whether she will 'compromise' on ChequersMr Watson replied: &ldquoI don&rsquot agree with that Andrew. At the very start of this process, Keir Starmer laid down the six tests. We have said that we will apply those tests to the deal when it comes through.&ldquoWe think that&rsquos a perfectly reasonable approach to take for Her Majesty&rsquos official opposition, that is there to hold the Government to account.&ldquoWe have said that we want a jobs first Brexit. I won&rsquot go through all the tests. We think that is a reasonable approach for us to take.&ldquoOver the course of the last 18 months, of course, we have forced the Prime Minister into concessions. We made the Government agree that they needed transitional arrangements, which will genuinely help companies in this area like Jaguar Land Rover who has already publicly spoken about their fears of a no deal Brexit.Speaking at the Labour Party conference this week, members of the shadow frontbench insisted their preference was a general election, over the prospect of a second referendum.Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer warned that the Labour Party would vote down any deal in Parliament if it did not meet their six tests.Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn urged the Prime Minister to make concessions on her Brexit plan if she wanted any support in the House of Commons.Addressing the conference on Wednesday, Mr Corbyn insisted Labour would not overturn Brexit but questioned the conduct of the May Government during the negotiations with Brussels.Mr Corbyn said: &ldquoLabour respects the decision of the British people in the referendum but no one can respect the conduct of the government since that vote took place.As it stands, Labour will vote against the Chequers plan or whatever is left of it and oppose leaving the EU with no deal. And it is inconceivable that we should crash out of Europe with no deal &ndash that would be a national disaster.Brexit news: Andrew Marr quizzed Tom Watson over Labour's Brexit strategy (Image: BBC)&ldquoThat is why if Parliament votes down a Tory deal or the government fails to reach any deal at all we would press for a general election. Failing that, all options are on the table. Brexit is about the future of our country and our vital interests.Prime Minister Theresa May accused the Labour Party of &ldquoplaying politics with Brexit during an interview on The Andrew Marr Show.Mrs May also called for her own party to get behind her controversial Chequers agreement, despite it facing huge criticism from within her own party.Before the Conservative Party conference, Mrs May said: &ldquoThe theme of Conservative party conference this year is&nbspopportunity. Two years on from the referendum, we&rsquove made progress in the Brexit negotiations at the same time as improving life for people here at home.But we&rsquore now at a crucial moment. The right deal is close &ndash and with it the opportunity to make life better for ordinary working people.So at this Conference, we will be setting out how we will provide&nbspopportunity&nbspfor all &ndash a stronger, fairer country with real opportunity for people who work hard and do the right thing.

title: italy news EU budget matteo salvini luigi di maio
story: The ruling parties - made up of the anti-establishment 5-Star Movement and the right-wing Lega - sent shivers through the eurozone after proposing a 2019 deficit that is, at 2.4 percent of gross domestic product (GDP), three times the previous administration's target.The announcement late on Thursday rattled markets on Friday, prompting a sell-off of bonds and a rout of banking stocks. It also set up a clash with the European Commission, which monitors and enforces EU fiscal rules.President Sergio Mattarella, who is separate from the elected Lega and Five Star Movement coalition, hinted he could vote down the budget and order it to go back to Parliament.POUND LIVE: GBP Sterling soars against euro as Italy sends panic through eurozone                Euro ON EDGE as Italy defies EU austerity to pass HUGE budget                Italy told to respect EU rules or face CONSEQUENCES as huge budget rowAddressing a group at the presidential palace that had marked the 70th anniversary of the constitution, he said the state's founding law requires balanced budgets and the sustainability of debt.He added: This is to protect the savings of our fellow citizens.A little later at a conference in central Italy, Bank of Italy Governor Ignazio Visco said the country's debt, the largest among big European Union economies at 131 percent of GDP, must not be allowed to increase.He said: Italy needs to favour public and private investment and to contain and reduce public debt.Luigi di Maio said those who had imposed austerity on Italy were thieves (Image: REUTERS)The debt must be put on downward path, he added.Matteo Salvini, leader of the League and also a deputy prime minister, responded to Mr Mattarella by saying that years of Brussels-imposed austerity had driven up debt.In a statement he said: Be calm Mr. President.Years of budgets imposed by Europe have made our public debt explode... finally we are changing course and betting on the future and on growth.Luigi di Maio celebrates on a balcony of Chigi Palace after passing Italy's budget (Image: EPA)Earlier, before either Mattarella or Visco spoke, Five Star leader Luigi Di Maio said the budget would repay the people for the thieving of the past, though he added the government's intention was not to challenge the EU or financial markets.The ruling parties pushed Economy Minister Giovanni Tria, who is an economist unaffiliated with either group, to sign off on their plans to hike deficit spending. Italian media said Mattarella had supported Tria's failed effort to keep the deficit target below 2 percent of GDP.The president and the central banker have no direct role in making economic policy.The 77-year-old president can reject a law and send it back to parliament, but he can do so only once. title: homework works parents help
story: He thinks he is stupid and that little Amy is clever because she knows all the answers.What he doesn’t realise is that Amy does her homework with her family every night.American comedian Rob Delaney ignited a lively debate when he tweeted: “Why do they give seven-year-olds so much homework in the UK and how do I stop this?I want my kid frolicking and drawing and playing football.”Fellow celebrities Gary Lineker and Jason Manford agreed.Piers Morgan disagreed, calling the arguments “lazy parenting”.I have to disagree too with Mr Delaney and his supporters.Homework is essential for a child’s education because revisiting the day’s learning is what helps to make it stick.So Catastrophe star Rob and Gary Lineker are wrong in attacking compulsory home-work in primary schools.Sure, you’ll get the odd exceptionally bright pupil who will excel just through what she learns at school, despite not having that support at home.But this is very rare.Teaching is not just the teacher’s job.It takes a village to raise a child.Children learn all the time and the environment surrounding them determines how much they learn.Genes play a part in how clever a child is, but how hard they work also matters.Work hard and you’ll learn lots.Work less and you’ll learn less.Don’t make the mistake of thinking homework is for a child to do on their own.When parents use homework to bond and learn together with their child, the child understands that Mum and Dad value learning.And because a child wants to please their parents, the child’s interest in their home-work will grow, year on year.These children can see the benefit of homework and will enjoy doing it because it makes them feel better about themselves.Everyone loves to feel successful.Ten years ago, author Malcolm Gladwell introduced the idea that it takes 10,000 hours of practice to become an expert in something.We get better at what we practise, whether it’s football or maths.Our brains have a working memory and a long-term memory.If your times tables are stored in your long-term memory, you will quickly be able to calculate what it will cost to buy 12 apples instead of two.If that knowledge isn’t there, you’ll have to resort to counting on your fingers.The more knowledge stored in long-term memory, the better equipped you’ll be to think imaginatively and solve complex problems.Homework revisits what you learn at school to cement it into your long-term memory.I do agree that some home-work is pointless.Silly craft projects that involve gluing things together, which the parent will inevitably end up doing, hold no value for me.I also understand why some parents don’t like homework — they feel that it’s a battle.Parenting is hard.I get that.But we need to stop thinking of homework as a chore that the child is sent off to do, cutting into the parent’s precious time with them.It shouldn’t be the case on Sunday night that Mum says: “Oh God, it’s homework time — let’s get it over with.”Instead, learning should be part of daily le, and an enriching time for both the parent and the child.Reading with your child for 20 minutes should not be a chore.Asking them to count peas on their plate should not be hard work.While you’re out in the street, talk to them about the world around them.This is the sort of homework that is often set for very young children and it can be done without making it feel like a formal lesson.It doesn’t need to be half an hour sitting at a desk.It can just be ten minutes of enjoyable time together.Homework can be written down but can also be spoken or done online, leaving little marking for the teacher.Secondary-school homework can help you learn with your child.You can learn some French again or be reminded of the beauty of Shakespeare!How wonderful is that?By scaffolding the support at home, you can gradually wean them off it, just like taking off bike stabilisers.Eventually, they learn to work independently, so that when they get to GCSEs, they will be in the habit of doing their homework each night.If you don’t get them into the homework habit from an early age, you risk having a battle with a stroppy teen as they approach their exams.And no parent wants that.Those who are against homework will argue that their children have no time for other hobbies.This is nonsense.Children generally finish school at 3.15pm, and younger ones tend to go to bed at about 8pm.That’s nearly five hours of free time.Are they really spending it playing hockey or going to Brownies?I doubt it.Half an hour of homework in five hours of spare time is a drop in the ocean, leaving lots of time for other things.The real worry for parents should be how much time children are spending on social media — something that is so very dangerous and takes up hours of their time, unlike homework.Katharine Birbalsingh is head of Michaela Community School, North London, and has been dubbed the country’s “strictest head teacher”.She introduced an ultra-disciplined approach to learning called Tiger Teaching.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says jeremy corbyn speech
story: It was his traditional blend of bile, fantasy and lies, falteringly recited in his two stock voices — all hammily-acted phoney compassion one moment, ­sudden exaggerated rage the next.He turned his ire first on Tories, then on a critical Press. This, he insisted, would remain free under Labour — but not just to print what it liked. Thick as he is, ­Corbyn sees no contradiction.Then it was on to Jezza curing all our ills with freebies galore and mass job creation, all presumably funded by the same tax on the rich. Since Labour aides now privately admit their 2017 manesto secretly covered up a £1TRILLION bill, Corbyn’s assurances aren’t worth the autocue they are written on.This smug, cocky Labour conference is an annual reminder of just what a dishonest rabble they now are. Sickeningly posing as defenders of the dispossessed while plotting to annul their Brexit votes with a second referendum, brought about by orchestrating chaos.One moronic MP even demanded a General Strike to oust the Government. Frontbencher Richard Burgon stood and applauded. And he is the “next Secretary of State for Justice”, God help us.Corbyn is keen to rebrand his extremism as mainstream in an era when capitalism has “failed”. It is, in reality, a dog-eared hard-left roadmap to ruin on a scale we have never experienced.A Britain which would kill ambition and enterprise and drive out successful firms by stealing their property. Where investors would fear to tread and from which anyone who could would flee.Labour’s candidate for PM is a dim, vain, vindictive, unapologetically anti­-Semitic ball of rage who loathes scrutiny, lies habitually about his true beliefs and past terrorist connections and is, his aides admit, “not good in the mornings”.But the Tories must not mistake all that for a free pass. Corbyn’s plans have traction only because the Government has left the battlefield.Theresa May and Philip Hammond are timid tinkerers when we need radical steps to put more money in pockets and make homes affordable. Socialism is the last thing we need. Next to last are Tory “Corbyn-lite” tax rises.Record job figures, low inflation and interest rates add up to a society and economy far healthier than the dystopia of chippy Corbynite imaginations.But  the Tories don’t fix the problems that DO exist they’re sunk, and Britain too.WELL done to Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson for swtly ensuring the kids of dying RAF officer Samantha McConnell will not be denied her pension.Now he must change the rules for good.So others like her get the same deal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn leave betray class
story: If selling out Leave voters doesn’t bother you then yes, Michel Barnier and Martin Selmayr — the German bully running the show — will delightedly hear how you intend to achieve it.Which explains why they were so keen to give him an audience yesterday.Betrayal is very much in Corbyn’s plans, as he made clear at his conference.Not only because his party is now firmly behind a second referendum with “Remain” as one of the options.But because he is also determined to stay in the EU’s Customs Union — and thus not leave at all.So, in the unthinkable event of a Labour Government seeing Brexit through, it would do so not via tough negotiations.It would be done by immediate capitulation to Brussels’ demands that the world’s fth biggest economy remain forever under their control.We would be barred in perpetuity from signing trade deals with the faster-growing giant economies of the wider world — and the central economic case for Brexit would be destroyed.So while Corbyn now suddenly claims to care for the forgotten working-class communities who backed Leave, they must never forget this: Labour is now controlled by its middle-class London Remainer membership, all desperate to overturn or negate Brexit.WE’LL be blunt, Becks.It is repugnant to see a celebrity smugly dodge justice solely thanks to being rich enough for a fancy lawyer skilled at exploiting loopholes.Especially when that star freely admits doing 59mph in a 40 zone.Millions of ordinary people grimly suck up fines they can ill afford for far lesser speeding offences.Even  their prosecution letter arrives a day late.Beckham may be within the letter of the law, but not its spirit.That’s a bad look for a man desperate for public adulation and establishment approval.Knighthood? It’s crashed and burned.WE hope the poll revealing voters in ­marginal seats deserting the Tories over sky-high rents is enough to stir the ­Government from its paralysis.The Tories are consumed by Brexit.But away from that they must wake up and present radical ideas to beat ­Corbyn’s, especially on housing.They have an advantage.Theirs are more likely to be sane.And vanishingly less likely to put hundreds of thousands on the dole.But Theresa May must realise that voters have more pressing problems than Brexit which could cost her power.Next week the Tories must have a new story to tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: james forsyth no home comforts to ease the brexit bind
story: In the bars and on the fringe, vigorous argument will rage about what the best Brexit option is for Britain.Cabinet ministers will whisper in corridors about what the Government should do next. Boris Johnson will draw a big crowd for his “Chuck Chequers” rally.But there is a bigger danger waiting in the wings for the Tories: They simply don’t have a domestic agenda big enough for the moment.Labour has, over the past few days, set out its vision for Britain. It is, in places, scary. But give Jeremy Corbyn and Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell this, it is undoubtedly clear and bold. As one Cabinet minister says, half admiringly:  “They’re hungry.”The Tories need to show  they have a better plan, one that will deal with people’s concerns— and they don’t have any time to waste. As one minister warns: “I’m just really terried. People don’t realise what a big deal this is.”The Tory Party’s problem is that it isn’t giving the country a vision of where it wants to take it. One former party leader has taken to lamenting that the Tories have “lost the narrative”.At conference last year, Theresa May declared that it was her mission to solve the housing crisis, to restore the British dream of home ownership for the many.But in the past 12 months, the Government has made far too little progress on this. Yes, some sensible steps have been taken. But the policies that will really solve this crisis, proper planning reform and a massive, Government-led housebuilding programme, haven’t happened.The result of all this: Jeremy Corbyn gets closer to power. As this newspaper revealed yesterday, Labour is now ahead in the seats that decide general elections thanks to its massive lead among renters.The likelihood of someone in their late twenties or early thirties on an average salary owning their own home has halved in the past 20 years.This is an electoral time bomb for the Tories. They can’t expect those without capital, or any prospect of getting it, to be capitalists.By the time of the next election, the Tories need to show people that their lives are getting better AND explain the damage  Corbyn would do to the country.One minister points the finger of blame at Number 10 for the Tory predicament. “A fish rots from the head down,” he tells me. But the Cabinet can’t escape its share of the blame, either.With a few exceptions, min­isters aren’t doing enough to take on Labour’s arguments. As one former Secretary of State fumed to me during Labour conference: “It’s outrageous. Where are the Cabinet?”If the Tories get Brexit wrong, it could cost them the next election. But even  they get a decent deal, it won’t guarantee them victory. For the public will vote on domestic issues — whether the housing crisis is solved, the state of the health service and what is going on with schools.Corbyn has simple answers to all these questions: They might be wrong, but they are answers. The Tories now need to show the country  they have answers too.AT last, some positivity and optimism about this country’s post-Brexit future from the Government.I can reveal  it is planning a major new festival celebrating the UK for 2022. The aim is for this festival to tell the world a story about Britain as we leave the EU and take charge of our own future. It is meant to coincide with the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee and the Commonwealth Games, which will be held in Birmingham that year.Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright,  who is pushing this idea in Whitehall, has told colleagues  it will be: “Future-facing, telling a story about the UK’s unique strengths, particularly as a place to invest, as we forge a new future outside the European Union.”If the Government gets it right, this festival could be a great statement about the open, dynamic country that Britain is going to be after Brexit. It should emphasise how this country is going out into the world after leaving the EU, not pulling up the drawbridge.The aim should be to put on something that stands comparison with the great post-war Festival of Britain in 1951 or even the Great Exhibition of 1851, which showcased Victorian Britain’s global reach and technological edge.One Secretary of State, who is backing the idea, tells me: “People just want something really positive.”But cynics might note that there is an advantage for the Tories in a feel-good festival in an election year.But I understand he will  have a harsh message for the Westminster politicians in attendance. He will  tell them to stop bickering and positioning and get on with delivering for the country.Mr Street will say that outside the Westminster bubble, the public just want politicians to get on with things, rather than constantly jostling for position.What makes his  speech so interesting is that he is a Downing Street favourite. Indeed, I understand  some of those close to Theresa May are pushing for a similar tone in her speech.They believe  her post-Salzburg speech went down so well with the public not just because she was standing up to the EU but because she was taking charge and being that “bloody dficult woman”. They think she should use her speech to tell members  they won’t get everything  they want from the Brexit talks, but that she will get the best deal for Britain.Others, though, are wary of this approach. One Cabinet minister cautions that after last year, May should play it safe as “you can’t have two bad years  in a row”.THE Government has rightly guaranteed that the three million EU citizens living in Britain will be able to stay in the event of no deal.This is sensible. These citizens contribute a lot to this country, and help keep our economy and our public services moving.But it is also right that the Government is now discussing what the rules will be for deporting EU citizens who commit crimes after Brexit in a no-deal scenario.The details have not yet been decided and, as one government source puts it: “No one wants people deported for getting a parking ticket.”But it is right that those who are convicted of a signicant offence are removed.• SPOT the leadership bid will be one of the games  the Tories play in Birmingham.Any Cabinet minister who starts talking about their childhood will be accused of planning a run for the top job.  This leaves ministers walking a tightrope as they prepare their speeches. Some are dealing with this challenge by handing their time  to others.Penny Mordaunt, the Aid Secretary, is simply introducing a series of “British heroes” who do development work.But one of those involved in conference planning suspects that even this is about leadership as Mordaunt “doesn’t want to spend 45 minutes defending the aid budget to a hall of Tory activists”.James Forsyth is political editor of The Spectator.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: indonesia tsunami traffic controller plane sulawesi
story: Anthonius Gunawan Agung was working at Mutiara SIS Al-Jufrie Airport on Friday night as devastation struck, but instead of fleeing, he stayed on the job to ensure a plane carrying hundreds of passengers took off safely.The 21-year-olds selfless actions saved the lives of hundreds of passengers on board Batik Air flight 6321 which was in the process of taking-off when the island nation was struck by disaster.Local reports confirm the tremors had left deep fissures in the runway and under the control tower.While Anthonius colleagues ran to safety, he remained in the crumbling tower until he safely guided the pilots into the air.Moments after the plane became airborne, the building began to shake violently, and fearing he would be trapped under debris, he made the decision to jump from a fourth floor window.The brave controller was rushed to hospital with a broken leg and a number of internal injuries, but he died in the early hours of the following morning.The news of his bravery comes as harrowing overhead images from the Indonesia quake and tsunami show the scale of the mass devastation that has left 832 people dead and thousands homeless.Sulawesi residents are tonight sleeping on the streets, as bodies covered in medical yellow sheeting remain scattered along the shoreline of the city of Palu.At least 384 people were killed after a tsunami, triggered by a magnitude 7.5 earthquake, tore through the Pacic Ring of Fire before crashing into the Indonesian coastal town at 500mph.According to local media, more than 500 people suffered serious injuries  in Palu alone.Disaster agency spokesman Sutopo Purwo said hundreds were taking part in a beach festival when the tsunami struck Palu at dusk on Friday.Indonesian authorities have been criticised for lting the tsunami warning just 34 minutes after it was issued, which led to many residents believing it was safe to head towards the beach in the scenic tourist town.The disaster struck on the same night as hundreds were preparing to celebrate the citys anniversary in lavish beach parties.As reality began to set it, thousands went searching amongst the yellow body bags littering the coastline for their relatives, as the scale of devastation and loss of le began to emerge.The nearby cities of Donggala and Mamuju were also ravaged, but little information was available due to damaged roads and disrupted telecommunications.Initial reports suggested victims died in the rubble of a collapsed building.Purwo said: We have not received comprehensive reports yet because communications are cut.Many bodies were found along the shoreline because of the tsunami, but the numbers are still unknown.Some of the injured, including Dwi Haris, who suffered a broken back and shoulder, rested outside Palus Army Hospital.Tears filled his eyes as he recounted feeling the violent earthquake shake the fth floor hotel room he shared with his we and daughter.I heard my we cry for help, but then silence. I dont know what happened to her and my child. I hope they are safe.Horrying footage which emerged shortly after shows the terrying moment people ran screaming after the devastating tsunami smashed the region.The video - reportedly taken on top of a shopping mall - shows the wave building up just off the shore.Just a few seconds later, the 7ft high wave can be seen crashing into the beach, immediately flattening houses in its path and submerging the entire area.Dwikorita Karnawati, who heads Indonesias meteorology and geophysics agency, BMKG, said panic gripped the city after the wave struck.She said the situation was chaotic with people running on the streets and buildings collapsing.Nina, a 23-year-old woman who goes by one name, was working at a laundry service shop not far from the beach when the quake hit.She said the quake destroyed her workplace, but she managed to escape and quickly went home to get her mother and younger brother.The three of us ran, but got separated. Now I dont know where my mother and brother are. I dont know how to get information. I dont know what to do.The quake rocked central Sulawesi in Indonesia just hours after a smaller tremor killed one and injured another 10.The US Geological Survey said the magnitude 7.5 quake was centred at a depth of 6miles about 35 miles northeast of the town of Donggala, Sulawesi.Indonesias meteorology agency initially issued an early tsunami warning for people in Central Sulawesi and West Sulawesi provinces, but this has since been lted.Earlier on Friday, the same area was hit by a magnitude 6.1 earthquake that killed one person, injured 10 and damaged dozens of houses.An official with the local disaster agency, Akris, said: Many houses have collapsed. It happened while we still have dficulties in collecting data from nine villages affected by the first quake. People ran out in panic.Donggala resident Mohammad Fikri said by telephone that he ran from his house but there wasnt great panic in his neighborhood.He said: All the things in my house were swaying and the quake left a small crack on my wall.But this was not the first time. Last week we felt an earthquake that had a stronger tremor so this time we didnt panic, just avoided the buildings and now everything has ed to normal.A series of earthquakes in July and August killed nearly 500 people on the holiday island of Lombok, hundreds of kilometres southwest of Sulawesi.Indonesia sits on the Pacic Ring of Fire and is regularly hit by earthquakes.In 2004, a big earthquake measuring 9.1 struck off the northern Indonesian island of Sumatra, triggering a tsunami across the Indian Ocean that killed 226,000 people in 13 countries, including more than 120,000 in Indonesia.

title: man finds biological dad super sperm donor 1000 siblings
story: Ivo van Halen, from the Netherlands, was told by his parents only five years ago that he had been conceived using a sperm donation sparking a search for his biological father.However, he was left stunned after genetic testing in Rotterdam identied not just his biological dad but at least 60 half-siblings in the Netherlands alone - and the potential for many more worldwide.Ivo was then informed that his dad was in fact an incredibly prolic sperm donor who had donated to at least three clinics on a regular basis over 20 years.According to one Dutch government agency, he may have fathered up to 1,000 children through his donations, which were supplied to the UK as well as clinics across Europe.The 34-year-old IT professional is now on the hunt to locate as many of his siblings as possible.He discovered his biological truths by using a £60 DNA testing kit from Family Tree DNA, as donor clinics abide by anonymity rules.The testing company lists biological relatives who have taken the same test and goes as far as estimating the relationship - i.e. siblings, parents - using the proportion of shared DNA.People share 50 per cent of their DNA with a parent and around 25 per cent with a half-sibling.Ivo decided to give it a go and submitted a saliva swab, before sitting back and waiting for the results.One month later, he was given the shocking news that he was one of hundreds of babies fathered by the same donor.Speaking to the The Times he said: “I found my biological father and 42 half-siblings right away.”Ivo reached out and made contact with several of his half-siblings, but it took a while longer before he contacted his biological dad.The pair hit it off immediately, with a shared love of puzzles helping them bond.Ivo has also connected with many of his half-brothers and sisters - some of whom grew up close to where he lived as a child.  He said: Some of the others had known each other before they found out they were related and had almost dated. Thats one reason this sort of knowledge is so important.”He is now on the hunt to trace his British siblings, and will use other DNA testing companies in the hope of making more connections.The story of Ivos biological dad can be compared to that of British scientist Bertold Wiesner, who may have fathered 600 children after making donations to a fertility programme he ran with his we.

title: karren brady the apprentice launch slippery excuses
story: Sixteen budding entrepreneurs battling it out to win £250k of Lord Sugar’s own money as an investment to start their own business.Alan goes into partnership with the winner — and that’s where Claude Littner and I come in.We are there to make sure he chooses the right person, by watching what happens when the contestants are out on tasks.People know it’s that time of year when they see Claude and I out on the streets with a notepad, pen and film crew.We don’t mentor, we don’t coach or give any guidance, we simply watch what unfolds. And what is amazing to me is how often people try to wriggle out of things and deny a decision they made, in a bid to stay in the process. So when they sit in the boardroom saying, “I didn’t . . . ” we can say, “Oh yes you did . . . ”Some people ask me  certain scenes are staged, but the show is unique in that there are no retakes, there is no setting up of scenes and no trying to find the comedy moment — they just come naturally.All of Alan’s jokes come naturally, too. There is no script, no autocue, it happens as it happens.Luckily, we get on very well — Claude, Alan and I. So much so that we all went on holiday together this year.We’re all quite similar, we have all been married for a long time and we all share the same family values.It makes us a watertight team, although we each bring something dferent to the table.But, parking that for a moment, The Apprentice is also top-notch entertainment — this series more than ever. What’s great about the first episode is that the contestants, all of whom talk the talk about how fantastic they are, are thrown into the deep end with a task that’s designed to test their logic.They are sent on what is a bit like a treasure hunt, in Malta, armed only with a map and some euros.This task is all about logistics, negotiation and identying, and let’s say it doesn’t end well.It turns out that, unfortunately, logic is not something all the contestants are in possession of.During this series we will travel all over the country, including to Glasgow to sell emerging artists’ work to the unsuspecting public.When I say that task was more challenging than ever, I’m referring partly to the challenge of actually getting to Glasgow because it was during the storms. Remember them?Turbulence was an under-statement. On the flight there, I was gritting my teeth and grabbing on to Claude like there was no tomorrow.One thing I love about the show is that there are equal numbers of men and women, and they are on a level playing field.Let’s face it, the same cannot be said out there in the “real” world.One thing I’ve been reflecting on over the course of my time on The Apprentice is how much things have changed for women in business since I started out.When I was having my kids 22 years ago, the very notion of “work-le balance” didn’t exist. But I’m pleased to say that working women aren’t trying to Have It All any more, and the days are gone when women feel the need to keep quiet about having kids at work.Women are now more able to demand flexible working and feel entitled to have time off for, say, ante-natal classes.More “mumpreneurs” are starting their own businesses. Still, you rarely catch working mothers using childcare as a reason for being absent from work — while men, I’ve noticed, almost get points for doing so.And it is still the case that working mothers and women working flexibly are less likely to be promoted.So I don’t quite agree with Ann Widdecombe, the former Tory MP, who wrote this week that women today have “never had it so good” yet still “whinge” about inequality.Because while it might be true that things have changed for the better, most CEOs are still male.Women might never have had it so good but it’s still not good enough — and it’s not “whingeing” to point that out.HONESTLY, watching Jeremy Corbyn forgetting Labour’s six tests for a Brexit deal, when interviewed by the BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg, was like watching a hapless buffoon.No wonder he got two Es at A-level.This is the leader of the party that makes it up as it goes along – buying votes, promising everyone everything . . . and delivering absoutely nothing.As Margaret Thatcher said, The problem with socialism is that you eventually run out of other people’s money.HERE, The Apprentice star Karren picks out some highlights to look forward to during the show’s new season . . .Wyatt said: “Bill Cosby is doing great . . . Mr Cosby knows that God is watching over him . . . he knows that these are lies.“They persecuted Jesus and look what happened . . .  I’m not saying Mr Cosby is Jesus, but we know what this country has done to black men for centuries.”Just to be clear, Cosby’s conviction has nothing to do with race.The man is accused of rape and drug-facilitated sexual assault, by an astonishing 60 women . . . of all races and ages including some as young as 17.He has finally been put in prison and his victims have justice. He is a vile rapist, a violent sexual predator.His sentence is based on his crimes, not his colour.Unlike Cosby – a “disgusting sexual deviant” according to one of his victims – Jesus was innocent of the crimes laid against him.Cosby, meanwhile, has admitted to giving sedatives to young women in order to have sex with them.In short, Cosby admits his crimes, the jury find him guilty and the judge sentences him.Attempts to make this out as a racial issue are simply ridiculous.I KNOW it’s hard for men to face up to losing their hair, but someone needs to tell David Beckham that by far the best approach when it happens is . . . acceptance.But, judging from the photos of him looking a bit like a smiling Brillo pad this week that is not the route he is taking.David,  you are reading this, you are a handsome man and no one cares  you have a thick head of hair or not – please don’t turn into Shane Warne.I guess the reality star has yet to realise no one is forcing her to go out.She just needs to learn the power of saying no.In the past, I had a dreadful habit of saying yes to an engagement when I meant no, then spent days trying to think of ways to get out of it.I completely changed my le when I decided to simply things by saying yes to an invitation when I wanted to go – and no when I didn’t.IT’S hard to believe not only that West Midlands Police are allowing “thrill-seekers” to spend Halloween in a cell used by serial murderer Fred West – but that they are charging them £75 to do so.Offering this “spooky ghost hunt” at the notorious Steelhouse Lane cells in Birmingham is in very poor taste – so disrespectful of West’s victims, including his daughter who is a surviving casualty of his and is clearly still suffering every day.No doubt the relatives of those West murdered still suffer every day, too.So the fact that a stay in his old prison cell is being offered as Halloween entertainment is positively ghoulish.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
