title: uk weather forecast britain hotter
story: NewsMet Office UK weather forecast: El Nino set to bring warmer-than-normal three months until ChristmasThe high temperatures mean 2018 could be one of Britain's hottest years everShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMark Chandler09:42, 30 SEP 2018Updated10:24, 30 SEP 2018News"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UK could see a hotter-than-normal three months until Christmas as the El Nino effect ramps up temperatures across the country - potentially making 2018 the warmest year on record. Following a frosty start to the week, the mercury will jump well above the 14C average in some parts on Tuesday, and could hit 21C later in the week. And, with further warm spells forecast in October and November, Met Office forecast models show a 60 to 80 percent chance of a warmer-than-average three months until the end of December. If September to December is 1.5C above average it could make 2018 the hottest year on record in the UK. That would give 2018 a 9.8C annual temperature, 0.9C above normal, nudging 2014’s record 9.91C.   The unseasonal surge will be driven by an incoming El Nino - a warming of the Pacic which boosts temperatures in October and November around western Europe. It is also being put down to warmth from the continent, alongside tropical air driven across the Atlantic by jetstream winds. The Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “2018 could push towards one of the hottest years on record. It’s a hot year even though it saw the ‘Beast from the East’ cold late winter.” Meanwhile, parts of Britain could be hotter than Barcelona this week as cold, as the frosty weather is replaced by surging temperatures. Many people will wake up to frost on Monday morning following a chilly weekend across a swathe of the country.  But the Met Office says temperatures will rise again in the south on Tuesday as a sweltering 2018 continues. And that could rise again in the following days, with a high of 21C possible in southern England, potentially making London hotter than Barcelona where temperatures are currently a degree lower.  Met Office forecaster Alex Burkill said: By Tuesday we could see a high of 18 or 19C in the south and we could just about nudge 20C.  Further north, it's going to be quite a bit cooler than that but still in the mid-teens. Around 14 or 15C is possible which is slightly above average for the start of October.  The amount of sunshine we get will play a massive part in how warm it feels.   And he said temperatures could tick up further still as we head further into the week. He said: Wednesday and Thursday could be a little bit warmer with perhaps a greater chance of 21C in the south. The upsurge in temperatures follows a chilly weekend in much of the UK, with some parts seeing the mercury drop below zero overnight. Katesbridge in Northern Ireland experienced the coldest night, with a low of -3.6C. And today will see showers and strong winds lash Scotland, spreading into Northern Ireland, parts of Wales and the north of England.

title: would you swallow human poo
story: NewsWould you swallow human POO to lose weight? Scientists believe they may have created the perfect pill to fight obesityScientists from New Zealand are trialling a new pill on overweight teenagers to see  the poo of a healthy fit person could alter the surface and inside bacteria of an overweight personShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGrace Witherden14:07, 30 SEP 2018NewsThe pill contains human poo "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSome people will try anything to lose weight but scientists from New Zealand believe they may have found the answer to weight loss with a 'magic pill'. There is just one catch - it contains human poo. The pill has been developed by researchers at the University of Auckland-based Liggins Institute, who are trialling it on overweight teenagers. The aim of the Gut Bugs Trial is to see  the poo of a fit, healthy person could alter the gut microbiome - bacteria that live inside and on the surface of our bodies, of an overweight person. This would in turn help them to lose weight and maintain a healthy weight.  Dr Justin O'Sullivan, a molecular biologist at the university said: The basic idea behind our trial is that by introducing more kinds of gut bacteria to obese young people, it will enable their bodies to metabolise food better, potentially leading to weight loss and other health benefits, such as lowering type 2 diabetes risk.” Earlier studies have shown that putting the gut bugs from lean mice into overweight mice led to dramatic weight loss The trial is believed to be the first in the world to study gut microbiome transfer in young adults with obesity.  The pills were made by isolating the gut bacteria from the stools of healthy lean donors and putting them into capsules which were then taken by overweight teenagers. Half the participants in the trial were given the bacteria capsules and half received a placebo - the results of the trial will not be revealed until mid 2019. A new documentary, The Good Sh*t, set to air in New Zealand, will follow four young women who took part in a piot version of the trial.

title: christine blasey ford should saluted
story: NewsopinionChristine Blasey Ford should be saluted for her 'courage' over Brett Kavanaugh sex claimsThe crimes of our youth should not be cut very much slack  they are alleged sexual assaultsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySaira Khan20:33, 29 SEP 2018NewsopinionChristine Blasey Ford "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe all make stupid &shymistakes when we’re young. Getting it wrong is how we grow up and learn to get it right. So when looking back at youthful misdeeds and misdemeanours it’s only fair to cut people a little slack. But when those mistakes are sex crimes, then the amount of slack that’s cut should be very, very small indeed. Dame Judi Dench touched on the issue this week when she was asked about her friend Kevin Spacey being replaced in films and TV shows in the wake of sex assault allegations. Spacey apologised for past behaviour but denied alleged assaults, some of which police are investigating.  Dame Judi said: “He is and was a most wonderful actor,” then asked  we would now “go back through history” to remove “anyone who has misbehaved in any way”. She has a point. We cannot just wipe all of Spacey’s work from the archive and pretend he never existed. But sexual assault is not just “misbehaving”, is it? It’s an offence, it’s a violation. It can damage a person’s mental health in a way that effectively destroys their le. Take TV legend Bill Cosby’s accusers. Only one of them, Andrea Constand, has seen justice. As the 81-year-old actor – described by the judge as a sexually violent predator – was carted off in handcuffs this week to begin a jail sentence of three to 10 years for assaulting her, I thought of the dozens of other women who bravely came forward to accuse him. Decades later they are still struggling to come to terms with being drugged and molested by a man we thought of as America’s dad, but who was actually the devil in disguise.  Because the time window for prosecuting him had passed, he never had to answer to any of them. Meanwhile, in any country you look at, only a small percentage of sex assaults ever get reported, a smaller percentage go to court and a tiny number result in convictions. To stand up in public and expose yourself to the hatred of someone who has already abused you, and the scorn of those who decided you were lying before you even opened your mouth, is a level of hell most of us will thankfully never know. So I salute the courage of psychology professor Dr Christine Blasey Ford who – despite admitting to being terried – told a US Senate hearing this week she believed Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh was going to rape her at a teenage house party in the 1980s. She claims the judge, Donald Trump’s conservative pick for the top US court, forced her on to a bed, tried to strip her, and covered her mouth to stop her screaming, leading her to fear suffocation. She was 15 at the time, he was 17. He says it never happened. Dr Ford earlier took a lie detector test, and passed. He has not taken one. Two other women have come forward to accuse Kavanaugh – one says he exposed his penis and shoved it in her face at a party. Another says he was present when she was gang raped at a party in the 1980s. He denies both offences.

title: great pumpkin asteroid shaped like
story: News'Great Pumpkin' asteroid shaped like SKULL set to fly past Earth just after HalloweenThe creepy comet, which was given its vegetable nickname by experts at NASA, is heading this way again after last visiting in 2015Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByPippa Allen-Kinross22:46, 29 SEP 2018NewsThe comet looks eerily like a skull "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A skull-shaped asteroid which has earned the nickname of 'Great Pumpkin' is set to fly past Earth just after Halloween .   The comet was first named after the spooky vegetable by scientists at NASA , after it flew past Earth on October 31, 2015.  Officially called the TB1456 asteroid, it came as close as 300,000 miles away from the planet back in 2015 - or 1.3 times the distance of the moon from Earth. It will be heading back this way on November 11, but is expected to be even further away and pass by at around 24 million miles away. This is about a quarter of the distance between the Earth and sun.  The asteroid has been described as a death comet, because it's believed to be a dead comet but also because of its unusual skull-like shape. First spotted by NASA's Infrared Telescope Facility  in Manua Kea, Hawaii, it's unnerving features were revealed on detailed radar images taken by the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico. In 2015, NASA said the comet was approximately 200ft  in diameter. At the time, Kelly Fast, IRTF program scientist at NASA, said: The IRTF data may indicate that the object might be a dead comet, but in the Arecibo images it appears to have donned a skull costume for its Halloween flyby.

title: as it happens dundee united v ross county
story: Cries of &#8216Csaba out&#8217 rang around Tannadice as United slumped to an embarrassing defeatShambolic, abject, and abysmal are all words that can be used to describe Dundee United&#8217s performance as they were humiliated on their own patch by Ross County.The Terrors were hopeless at the back and pretty blunt going forward as the Staggies romped to all three points. It is hard to defend United manager Csaba Laszlo now and it would be no surprise  he is given his jotters after this most horric of days.It started when eventual hat-trick hero and former Tangerine Billy Mckay opened the scoring from close range on 11 minutes, knocking in a Josh Mullin cross.The only chink of light in the game came six minutes later as Pavol Safranko got on the end of Fraser Aird&#8217s delivery to guide the ball past Scott Fox in the away net.From there United laboured and County took advantage. Scoring the most simple and avoidable goals &#8211 often carbon copies of each other.The second came on 29 minutes after a Jamie Robson mistake played in Mullin to square for Mckay to knock in.On 41 minutes the same problems United had faced all game down their left-hand side were there for all to see as Sean Kelly inswinging free-kick went all the way through past Matej Rakovan in the home net. A horrible goal to concede with no communication evident and the defence at sixes and sevens.Soon after the restart the Staggies put the game to bed when Mullin and Mckay linked up again with the former this time tapping in from a yard out on 50 minutes.Mullin turned provider, once more, two minutes later laying Mckay&#8217s hat-trick on a plate for him and the Northern Irishman gobbled it up from a matter of inches out.Csaba tried to change things for the Tangerines, but by this point the punters had seen enough and were leaving in their droves and calling for his head in the process, as he brought on Stewart Murdoch and Fraser Fyvie to try to change things on 56 minutes.And three minutes later Murdoch summed up the Terrors afternoon as he was shown a straight red for a stamp on Jamie Lindsay.It capped what was United&#8217s worst performance in years as County saw out the rest of the game with little problem. Is it time up for Csaba?Full details in live blog.&nbsp

title: cammy kerr calls on dundee to show dee fiant spirit
story: Cammy Kerr has called on everyone at Dundee to revive the Dee-fiant spirit to get out of the trouble they find themselves in at the bottom of the Premiership table.The 3-0 home defeat to Hibs last weekend leaves the Dark Blues still stuck on zero points after six league fixtures.A lelong fan of the club, Kerr, however, knows Dundee have got through tougher situations than this in their history.Though he admits they’ll need exactly the same “character” as the club showed to overcome a 25-point deduction in 2010  they are to get off the foot of the ision.He said: “As you see the games going and the points staying the same, it is dficult but that’s why you are a football player and have got to this stage and you need to deal with ups and downs and struggles along the way.“This club has had plenty of struggles in its time, it’s had points deductions and all sorts of things – it’s now about showing that character within the club that I believe no other club has.“We just have to find that within ourselves and push it on and make sure nothing stops us in this search for a victory.“We had a poor start a couple of years ago but we turned things around and that’s what I’m trying to get at.“It’s so dficult but being a Dundee fan and seeing things the way I have over the years, I know there is nothing that should allow this club to say no.“Everyone pulling together, the office staff, kitchen staff, the youth boys, everyone, just keep smiling, keep plugging away and it’s going to turn, I’m positive of that.”Honest as ever, Kerr admits this season just plainly hasn’t been good enough from Dundee.“If you let things get out of hand it’s like a disease that spreads,” he added.“It’s all confidence-related and, as the manager spoke about before, we just need a goal to get us in front.“However, at the same time,  we are going behind in games, we can show resilience that we don’t lie down but fight for every ball, every tackle, everything we have in us, we keep fighting to the end. We just seem to be falling short just now and it’s not good enough.“There’s nothing else for it, it’s the same old cliched stuff – you’ve just go to keep fighting away.“You need to be ready to go on the training field, pushing yourself to the max every day.“We have to put in the hard yards and that’s the only way it will turn.“I know the fans and everyone at the club is frustrated, they’re obviously used to seeing better times than this, but there is still time to get our season going.“That’s the only positive – there’s another game in a few days’ time, a massive game against Hamilton and we’ve got to go and make sure we get a victory.“I know, it’s easy saying that and the punters will be sick to the back teeth of people saying ‘next week, next week’ but it’s the only thing for it.”Hamilton against Dundee has been a grudge match over the past few years and last season at New Douglas Park was one of the stand-out moments for the Dark Blues as they came from behind to win the game in the 97th-minute through A-Jay Leitch-Smith.Kerr added: “Last season at Hamilton was amazing, an incredible finish to the game and that again was a resilient performance full of character within the group.“It’s dficult being positive after Saturday’s defeat and having no points from the first six games but we have to go there, knowing how hard it is down there, it’s an absolute dogfight.“They got a great result last week but it’s a game of football, 90 minutes, and  we get ourselves on top we can win the game on Saturday.”

title: coffee giant starbucks plans to open second drive thru in dundee
story: Coffee giant Starbucks could open a second drive-thru branch on Dundee’s ring road in the near future.The chain opened its first drive-thru at Wester Gourdie Industrial Estate earlier this year, and has now submitted a proposal for another.If approved, the branch would occupy land on Afton Way, close to the city’s Morrisons store.Representatives for Morrisons, which owns the entire site at Afton Way, say the planned shop would match the “signicant” growth of drive-thru coffee shops across the country.It would also serve a iety of people from passing motorists on the A90 through to nearby residents.The new proposal,  approved by Dundee city planners, would also create new jobs, and contribute to ongoing regeneration efforts in the North East.In a statement, representatives for Morrisons said: “The proposed small-scale drive- thru unit will form a complementary addition to the existing Morrisons store.“It will also generate a number of job opportunities for local people.”The application also hints at further development to come at Afton Way.Initial talk of an expansion on the site began as early as January 2013 – with other potential developments in future including a pub.Diagrams included with the Starbucks proposals detail a new, more convenient entrance to the site from the southbound A90 Forfar Road.However, this is likely to form part of a separate planning application in due course.And Morrisons also had a plan to mody and expand its petrol station approved in October last year.Starbucks’ latest move to build on Dundee’s ring road comes at a time of intense interest from developers on the Kingsway.Alongside the now-opened Starbucks drive-thru at Myrekirk, plans have also been approved for a retail complex on Kingsway East at Craigie.That development will boast a Lidl, a car dealership and a Costa Coffee drive-thru.Starbucks also has a sit-in coffee shop at the Overgate Centre.

title: csaba happy to be able to call on quality as dundee united prepare for ross county
story: Boss Csaba Laszlo will be pleased to be able to turn to his bench for support as his Dundee United side host Ross County at Tannadice.Csaba will welcome club captain Fraser Fyvie back to the fold after he missed last Saturday’s 2-0 win over Falkirk due to him not being risked on the articial surface so soon after recovering from a knee injury.He will be joined in the matchday party by winger Billy King as a few other absentees fight back to contention.“With these players coming back it will create more competition and up the quality in training,” Csaba said.“Sam Stanton and Stewart Murdoch are back in training with the team, while Nicky Clark will need another week.“It is important to get these players back to speed.”On Fyvie, Csaba added: “It was a frustration to have a player that can’t play.“We also have to accept that he is a player who has been injured long-term.“It has not just been an easy injury that takes a little time to recover from.“Psychologically, you must also be ready for this kind of match.“As a manager, you have to accept it when a player says ‘This isn’t the best game for me, on the articial pitch’.“For that reason he didn’t play but he will be OK for the Ross County match.”One player Csaba has, sadly, ruled out for the forseeable future is Lewis Toshney.“He has been out for a year so it is not easy for him.“He is fighting to come back.“I am happy that he can train but I don’t think we can talk just now about the first team.”

title: designer says maggies penguin parade in dundee can inspire future artists
story: The success of charity art trails highlights the positive effect sculpture can play in bolstering civic pride, a University of Dundee academic has said.Janice Aitken, associate dean for public and community engagement at Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and Design, said that the success of campaigns like the city’s Maggie’s Penguin Parade would also help to inspire future generations of artists.Janice, who created the original design used for the cancer charity’s summer fundraiser, made the comments ahead of speaking at Dundee Arts Cafe this coming Tuesday.“It’s very important to celebrate a rich culture and heritage in any community,” she said.“Having a sense of fun and civic pride makes any city a more positive place to live.”Janice will speak about the benefits of public art and her association with the Penguin Parade, which saw 80 dferent sculptures put in place throughout Dundee over the summer.

story: Dundee boss Neil McCann is hoping his walking wounded recover in time for today’s vital Premiership game against Hamilton kicks off.The Dens gaffer is under pressure to arrest his side’s run of straight defeats – six in the league, seven in all competitions – as the Dark Blues head to Lanarkshire to take on Accies.Martin Canning’s men sit on six points and can move nine clear of their relegation rivals with a second win in two, after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren last week.Neil will have at least one addition to his options after winger Roarie Deacon declared himself available for action.After a y period out, caused by an injury to his ankle picked up in the last game of last season against Partick which required surgery, it’s likely the former Arsenal man will have to settle for a place on the bench.Last week’s 3-0 defeat to Hibs saw Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all limp off.Finnish striker Kallman’s problem was cramp and won’t keep him out today while Madianga and Miller’s injuries were muscle based and it remains to be seen how long they may be out for.The club are hopeful Josh Meekings will be back fit after a thigh injury picked up against Motherwell four weeks ago.He missed the defeat to Hibs, though, Neil may be tempted to stick with his two loan signings Andy Boyle and Ryan Inniss in any case.At the top end of the field, the Dens boss will be hoping targetman Sofien Moussa has recovered from his knock picked up before the loss to Hibs to give him another option in attack.Meanwhile, Kenny Miller will serve the final game of his two-match suspension today.

title: dundees bid for big oil projects rejected because port is too shallow
story: Dundee’s bid to become a centre for large-scale oil and gas decommissioning projects was rejected because the approach to the port is “too shallow”.Despite owner Forth Ports investing £10 million to ensure the port was capable of handling large-scale projects,  Shetland was chosen this month as the best site to carry out large-scale oil and gas decommissioning.Consultants Ernst and Young decided Dundee was unsuitable after just the first of its three testing stages.Its full report is still to be published but energy minister Paul Wheelhouse revealed the reason for Dundee’s rejection in a response to a written parliamentary question by Conservative MSP Bill Bowman.He said the approach to the docks only has a depth of six metres, not the nine required, and with dredging work, the approach to Dales Voe in Shetland will be 24 metres deep.He said: “Although Dundee is suitable for a range of decommissioning works, because the approach depth was insufficient for those projects requiring a deep water port, it was therefore not assessed further than Stage one.”Stuart Wallace, chief operating officer of Forth Ports, which owns the Port of Dundee, hit back, saying the dock was easily capable of handling large-scale decommissioning work.He said: “The Port of Dundee has the largest permanent quayside crane, strongest quayside and biggest indoor decommissioning facility in Scotland.“Dundee regularly welcomes large jack-up rigs into the Tay and can handle all vessels any other east of Scotland port can accept.“There are only three vessels operating in the market that require 30m+ water depth, however this is a very small part of the market.“With additional investment, the approach channel to the port could be enhanced.”Mr Bowman said: “It is disappointing to be told Dundee did not pass the first test, although the SNP has still yet to publish the details.”

title: exclusive argentina legend claudio caniggia to return to dundee
story: Dundee fans haven’t had much to cheer recently but they will be given a lt with news Claudio Caniggia is set to make a  to the city.The 50-times capped Argentine international – and former strike-partner of Diego Maradona – will be back in Dundee at the Whitehall Theatre on Thursday November 29.Caniggia will be joined on stage by renowned Dundee-supporting journalists Patrick Barclay and Alan Patullo, to discuss his World Cup heroics, that goal against Brazil, his time in Italian football, being offered the chance to  to the national team at 43 years of age, and, of course, his time with the Dark Blues.His arrival at Dens Park 18 years ago, stunned Scottish football and attracted international media attention.Although 33-years-old when he signed for Ivano Bonetti’s Dundee in September 2000, a debut goal at Pittodrie proved there was no doubt that he would still be a star in the Scottish game.Despite being at Dens for less than a season, Caniggia remains idolised by the Dundee supporters and was inducted in to the Club’s Hall of Fame in 2009.The evening will be hosted by broadcaster David Tanner.During his time at Dens, Caniggia wore the No 33 shirt each time he played. Accordingly, tickets for the event are priced at £33.Tickets – including a limited number of VIP Meet &amp Greet briefs – are on sale from 9am tomorrow morning by logging on to thelongestforty.&nbspHelp For Kids are the event charity partner, with a donation being made to the charity for the benefit of local children, and tickets being made available for families who might not have otherwise been able to attend.

title: hamilton boss martin canning wont be shed a tear for under pressure dundee counterpart neil mccann
story: Hamilton boss Martin Canning insists he cannot afford to take any notice of Neil McCann’s plight ahead of Saturday’s clash with bottom side Dundee.Pressure is piling on the Dens Park manager after six straight Ladbrokes Premiership defeats and a Betfred Cup exit to Ayr United.However, Canning noted his side beat St Mirren 3-0 at home on Saturday for their first win in four matches, to give Accies some respite of their own.He said: “You’ve got to go and do your own job and my job on Saturday is to try to get Hamilton Accies three points and  we can do that we’ll be delighted.“That’s just football. We know Dundee will be desperate for the points.“We’ve got to make sure we match that and that gives us the best opportunity.“We’re all going to have spells when things don’t go our way.“I’m pretty sure, same as I do, he’ll believe in his players that they can go and win games and he’ll work hard to try to make that happen.“One result can make you feel a lot better.“I think at times last season, half-a-dozen clubs went through runs of losing four, five, six games and it can happen in this league quite easily.“I thought Dundee were good against St Mirren – very good.“The goalkeeper makes a mistake and they lose the game and from there it snowballs into a poor run of results, so it can happen so easily.“The flip side of it is, you go and win two or three games in a row and it’s a completely dferent complexion.”

title: neil mccann urges his dundee players to give themselves an easier ride
story: Neil McCann has urged his players to “give themselves an easier ride” at Hamilton on Saturday as they search for a first result of the campaign.The Dark Blues have endured a woeful start to the Premiership season, losing their opening six fixtures and scoring just twice.At the start of that run was also a 3-0 home defeat in the Betfred Cup to Ayr United, making it seven defeats on the trot.In none of those matches have Dundee managed to put themselves in front and their gaffer is desperate for the players to at least give themselves a chance of picking up a result.In order to do that, they’ll have to get the better of an Accies side high on confidence after a 3-0 thumping of St Mirren in match that has had a bit of extra spice over the past few years.And despite extra pressure on him to get the result, Neil still has faith in his side.He said: “It’s a huge game, they always have been against Hamilton.“The games against Livingston, Hamilton, Kilmarnock are going to be so important and then Hibs and Hearts.“We are still striving for that first win and we’ll keep trying to give everything to get ourselves that first goal that can at least put ourselves in a position to go and get that first win.“I still think that you could see in the first 45 minutes last Saturday, there is a team there.“I would just love to see them give themselves an easier ride by putting themselves in front.”The Dens gaffer is also hopeful of having some extra bodies back fit after a punishing injury-hit spell.Josh Meekings, Genseric Kusunga, Nathan Ralph and Sofien Moussa all missed the defeat to Hibs with injury while Kenny Miller was suspended.He’ll also miss Saturday’s trip to Hamilton while Kharl Madianga, Calvin Miller and Benjamin Kallman all added to the injury worries last weekend.The good news is winger Roarie Deacon is nearing a  after getting 45 minutes under his belt in a bounce game this week.Neil added: “We’ve not had an easy run of it and it’s been tough to get a settled side out.“We had Glen Kamara and Ryan Inniss back from injury lay-offs on Saturday but it’s been problematic in terms of that.“I have been happy with the squad,  I can get them all fit it would be welcome but we’ve not been able to get that.”

title: taysiders getting happier while fife folk becoming more anxious report
story: People living across Tayside are getting happier while those in Fe have experienced a signicant rise in anxiety, according to a report by the Office for National Statistics.Angus has seen the biggest jump in happiness anywhere in the region with a 2.7% increase on the previous year.During the same period, Dundee saw a rise of 0.9%, while Perth and Kinross experienced a dip of 1%.Fe also suffered a decrease in happiness, dropping 0.9% following a sharp rise the year before, but charted a further decline across the three other wellbeing factors covered in the report.The report notes key influences that determine overall happiness, including local factors such as crime, community cohesion, employment and education.People living in the Western Isles were found to be the happiest anywhere in the country, while those in the Highlands were the happiest on the mainland.Scotland remains the second happiest nation in the UK overall, second only to Northern Ireland, with England taking up last place.Scots are 0.7% happier than they were in 2016-17 but the data shows a decrease in the longer term, with a 2.6% fall since the earliest records in 2011-12.Dundee saw a 3.2% rise in le satisfaction and a 3.4% increase in terms of how worthwhile people think their actions are, but also experienced a sharp rise in anxiety levels.Locals in Dundee experienced an 8.9% increase from the previous year, with only Fe reporting a bigger jump across the area at 11.1%.Toni Giugliano, policy manager at the Mental Health Foundation Scotland, warned that there is a “very clear link” between areas with high levels of social deprivation and mental ill-health.

title: we are not manchester city csaba explains why he feels being dundee united boss is the hardest job in scottish football
story: There were some cursory glances around the Press room at the Falkirk Stadium after Dundee United’s 2-0 win on Saturday when boss Csaba Laszlo, almost out of nowhere, asserted the following.“The most dficult job in the Scottish Championship, or Scottish football at the moment, is to be the manager of Dundee United.”He qualied that statement by adding that it is also dficult for his players to pull on the black and tangerine but his remarks did pique the interests of those gathered.It wasn’t so much disagreement or astonishment that filled the room but more a sense of being taken aback by the brutal honesty of a man who has been under such pressure of late.He eased some of the weight on his shoulders with the result at Falkirk under what were strange circumstances – namely going up against predecessor Ray McKinnon in the opposite dugout for a side sitting bottom and pointless.And it was clear that, despite assertions by some that Csaba is daft or clueless, he was very aware of the ramications had he not got the right result.“We showed good team spirit under pressure, they handled it positively,” Csaba commented as he laid out his case to the gathered press.“Now we can close this chapter and look ahead to the next game which will be very dficult.“This is the third season where the fans have been disappointed to be in the second tier and we are talking about a very massive, strong and passionate club that wants to be in Premiership.“If something doesn’t go right immediately you have noise which is OK but we don’t want to hide behind anything.“We have this pressure and we have to accept.“We don’t want to spend one more year in the Championship – it’s not good.“The Dundee United fans don’t want to hear that from the board, the manager or anybody. They want to have the target of promotion and winning the league.“This is pressure, this is normal but you have to understand we have a budget that isn’t any higher than other teams in the main.“You have to bring a team together. We had 19 players leave and 16 players come in for the new season.“We can’t click our fingers and have the team work fantastically.“There are rules at the club about how many or which kind of players we can bring in within our budget.“It is not easy, we are not Manchester City with an owner behind you who can give you £20 million to go and spend.“We have to work with the budget we have to get the best for the club.“The Dundee United board have done a fantastic job. It is not easy to convince players from abroad to come to the Scottish Championship with everything else around.”It was quite a defence – but probably one that was coming after weeks of trying to keep a lid on it following poor results against Alloa and Morton.Yes, he has not had his troubles to seek with injury and scrutiny from all angles but it seems to be just the beginning for Csaba in his most tough of jobs.In the next four weeks they take on title rivals Ross County, Ayr United, Partick Thistle and Inverness. They kick off that run at home to County on Saturday.“I don’t just look at one game being more important than the other because you can’t afford to take any game lightly,” Csaba added. “You have to take every opponent seriously, whether they be at the top, middle or bottom of the league.”

title: xplore bosses apologise for disruption to dundee buses due to driver shortage
story: BUS bosses have apologised following claims dozens of services have been cancelled in the last few weeks.Xplore Dundee says a shortage of drivers is causing serious disruption to routes throughout the city.One passenger claims he spent almost an hour waiting for a service as a result.The Tele understands dozens of cancellations have occurred, with many being announced on electronic boards at bus stops.Normal service is still to resume, but a spokeswoman for Xplore Dundee said they are “seeing improvements”.She said: “We’re sorry for the disruption currently affecting some of the services in our network and for any inconvenience caused to customers. We’re currently experiencing operational dficulties due to a temporary driver shortage. This issue is being actively worked on and we are already seeing improvements.“To keep passengers up to date, the real time information boards within shelters are programmed to show any change to services. All the relevant authorities have been informed of this situation and are being updated regularly on our progress.“Once again, we apologise for this short-term reduction in service and want to reassure customers we’re working very hard to resolve this as quickly as we can to resume normal operations.”A spokesman for the Traffic Commissioner’s office, which deals with complaints relating to bus operators, said they were aware of the current issues in relation to the punctuality of Xplore Dundee services but could not comment on a pending case.Back in June, the Traffic Commissioner fined Xplore Dundee £8,700 after repeated complaints about late and early-running services throughout the city.A report was submitted by Bus Users Scotland about punctuality failings and the services cited included the 9, 10, 15, 17 and 23 buses.The financial penalty was imposed after the Traffic Commissioner opted not to pursue a further investigation into the issues.One bus user, who wished to remain anonymous, said he found himself waiting almost an hour for a bus to Charleston last week. He said: “Journeys are basically going missing as far as I can see.“I have a family member who works for Xplore and it seems drivers are going off sick and they can’t replace them.“Myself and other people have been waiting up to an hour for buses – it’s shocking.“It was only the other week that I was waiting on a bus to go to Charleston and all I was seeing on the electronic board was that it had been cancelled.“The company weren’t able to send another one on and I was having to wait, that really shouldn’t be happening.“As far as I am aware this has been going on for quite a few weeks now. There’s no signs of it getting any better but something needs to be done about it.“I was informed that the Traffic Commissioner was aware of it so hopefully they will take it seriously.”

title: Blainie 9 defies the odds in charity race
story: &nbsp&nbspIn 2016, Blainie White  was diagnosed with a form of Batten disease which affects just eight people in the UK. It is a neurological condition which causes gradual loss of sight and movement, leaving the schoolgirl wheelchair-bound.The condition also causes Blainie to suffer from epilepsy.However, a team of dedicated family and friends have rallied round to raise money for specialist equipment which could transform her quality of le, and helped Blainie complete the Baxters River Ness 5KM race last Sunday.Her proud dad Scott  said: &ldquoThere was a full squad of us out doing the run and that was fantastic. It was really good for Blainie to be able to do it.&ldquoShe was really enjoying all the noise and the music. You would never have thought that she would be able to do it, but she did.&ldquoWe have raised nearly &pound700 just through doing the run, which is brilliant.The family are raising money for a flotation device which will allow Blainie to swim, as well as a robust wheelchair to help her enjoy the great outdoors.&ldquoShe just loves going in the pool, Mr White said.&ldquoHowever, it' between &pound700 and &pound800 for a device.&ldquoWe are also looking at getting another wheelchair as well because we need one that' a bit bigger for when she' outside school.&ldquoWe are always out doing walks which is another reason we need a more robust wheelchair for her.&ldquoGetting out and about in the fresh air is something she really enjoys, but it also helps with her condition because it tires her out.&ldquoSleep is so important because  she doesn&rsquot get enough, that heightens the seizures.Blainie' cause is also being championed by the Royal Bank of Scotland, where three relatives work.The bank' staff in Inverness have picked the Batten Disease Family Association as their chosen charity for next year.&ldquoRBS have taken BDFA on as their charity of the year which is absolutely fantastic, Mr White added.&ldquoMy partner Laura and her sister both work at the bank and her other sister is the manager so I just kept pestering them. Every year they have a charity they pick and for them to pick the BDFA is brilliant.&ldquoAny money RBS raised will be doubled by the bank as well which is a huge bonus for us We are really grateful.Mr White says his daughter continues to inspire the family on a daily basis.&ldquoShe can&rsquot walk or talk any more, but she is always laughing and giggling, he said.&ldquoShe does get a lot out of le. She' an inspiration to us all.- To donate to Blainie' fund, visit justgiving/crowdfunding/littlebeesbattleSunday 30 Sep 2018 2:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Entrance to Victorian Market to get facelift
story: WORK&nbspcould begin on the Victorian Market' makeover as early as January.Highland Council has submitted planning applications to improve the appearance of the Academy Street entrance to the complex, which dates back to 1869.The plans involve bringing the glazed screen closer to the street in order to improve visibility into the market.The local authority says this will make the site more accessible, as well as improving security by reducing the number of access points on Academy Street to one.An uplighting system is also set to be installed in order to highlight the historic architecture of the building, and signage will be removed to &ldquo historic integrity to the Academy Street facade.The project marks the first stage of an action plan, which is being implemented by the council and the Inverness Common Good Fund, which is also set to build a business case for the remodelling of the market hall.No timescale for the completion of the work has yet been finalised, but an application for a grant of &pound30,250 has been submitted to the Inverness Townscape Heritage project.The news of the redevelopment came just days after traders in the Queensgate Arcade section of the market spoke of their struggle to deal with ongoing issues with the complex roof.Businesses in the privately-owned section of the building have been forced to take action to deal with repeated leaks which have at times forced them to close.Toni Rutherford, of the Little Teapot cafe, believes businesses in the market need help to deal with the problem.&ldquoIt is really frustrating for us that this problem keeps reappearing, she said.&ldquoIt' not good, especially when you walk into the arcade and see all the buckets.&ldquoIt' not a good impression for customers.&ldquoWe understand that there will be issues with the age of the building but that' all the more reason to take care of it, especially  people are wanting to make all these improvements to the building.&ldquoThree quarters of the building is owned by the council but the section we are in is privately owned.&ldquoThat means that any issues with the roof in our section have to be dealt with by us as traders.&ldquoThere have been times where we have had to close because of it. We have had waterfalls coming into the tearoom while customers have been in.&ldquoAlthough dferent sections of the building are owned by dferent people we are all under one roof, so we feel there should be some help available for the situation.&ldquoEveryone in the building needs to come together to get the problem solved.Sunday 30 Sep 2018 2:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Gay pride march to go ahead
story: &nbspA gay pride march through the centre of Inverness has been given the go-ahead.Proud Ness, which will take place on October 6, has been at the centre of a bitter row after Donald Morrison, a home mission worker with the Free Church of Scotland , submitted a petition to Highland Council signed by 600 people opposing the event on "biblical, religious and moral grounds".In response, thousands of supporters signed counter petitions, saying gay pride was celebrated all over the world and the people of Inverness wanted to be on the right side of history.The council confirmed this morning the march can go ahead."We have notied the organisers that Highland Council and Police Scotland have no objections to the march being held as per the details in their notice of intention," the spokeswoman said.Previously, the spokeswoman said the petitions from both sides would not have a bearing on the decision process as the raised matters of concern were not sufficient reason to refuse the parade.Sunday 30 Sep 2018 2:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Horror over plan for hundreds of trucks to pass Inverness school
story: &nbsp&nbspThe six-month operation, which is due to begin next spring, would take the lorries via Cloverfield Road, the southern distributor route, B8082 and onto the A9.Contractor, forestry management company Scottish Woodlands, has told Highland Council it has reached agreement with a neighbouring farmer for a track to be upgraded to give lorries access to the woods.But local community figures say that does not address the issue of public safety.The firm says the work at Balvonie Woods is essential.Inverness South councillor Ken Gowans said: &ldquoThis involves 480 truck journeys. To put that size of truck through a residential area, past Inshes Primary, is an unacceptable risk not to mention the disruption that could cause to the community. Some of the school community were horried at the prospect.Inverness South Community council secretary Bob Roberts said: &ldquoNo matter what they do the lorries will pose problems.&ldquoI&rsquom very concerned for the pupils&rsquo safety because as well as this, at certain times of day the parking around the school is horrendous.The community council is still to formulate its official response to Highland Council.Scottish Woodlands&rsquo regional development manager Bruce Taylor said: &ldquoIt' quite early days. There&rsquoll be a consultation period from now until the end of the year and we&rsquoll look at all options.&ldquo The point is to raise the proposal into the public arena and get responses with an expectation that we would be attending community council meetings to discuss the matter.&ldquoAt the end of the day, the wood is becoming unsafe because there is wind-throw in it and we need to find a solution to it because the owner is becoming concerned that at some point somebody might get hurt by a fallen tree.Dates are still to be arranged for consultation events.Sunday 30 Sep 2018 2:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Just get on with it Eastgate Hostel owners told
story: &nbsp&nbspPat Hayden, chairwoman of Crown and City Centre Community Council, said the owners should &ldquostart now and stop making excuses after they said they were &ldquofocusing 100 per cent on moving forward with plans to finally tackle the eyesore.Owners Imtaiz Ali and a Mr Cheng recently said they hoped a contract for demolition could be in place before the end of November, but work may not start until after the festive period to avoid inconveniencing neighbouring traders.In answer to further questions posed to them by the Courier, through agent Gary Johnston of GH Johnston Building Consultants, they also revealed more about their plans for the shop spaces and two holiday apartments set to be created when the building is restored.&ldquoMr Cheng intends to reinstate his quality food takeaway restaurant, Mr Johnston said.&ldquoThe other shop unit will be available for rent as a class one shop, restaurant, hot food takeaway or other business considered suitable in the town centre. This may require a further planning application to Highland Council.&ldquoThe holiday apartments are aimed at visitors to Inverness and the Highlands and are commensurate with similar holiday lets in the High Street.&ldquoAs the apartments will be new and with a generous floor area, they will be at the higher end of the quality lets.They owners said they would take &ldquosoundings from Inverness Business Improvement District in terms of when would be the best time to start demolition work and refused to discuss why it had taken more than 2000 days to get anything done.Mr Johnston said: &ldquoThe owners will not make any comment on the past as they are now focusing 100 per cent on moving forward to get the scaffolding off the street and starting on the rebuild.But Mrs Hayden said she wanted to see action as soon as possible and there had been enough talk in the city about moving things forward.&ldquoStart now and don&rsquot use Christmas as an excuse. Get [the scaffolding] down. Today' a lovely day to start, she said.&ldquoWe&rsquove had enough excuses &ndash I&rsquom fed up of excuses.She said that when the fire happened her grand-daughter had been an infant, adding: &ldquoThat grand-daughter is about to be seven. That puts it in perspective &ndash it' been far too long.&ldquoAction is what is needed. Never mind consulting everybody &ndash everyone in that area wants rid of the scaffolding.&ldquoDon&rsquot wait until after Christmas because then the weather will be bad and then there&rsquoll be another excuse.Sunday 30 Sep 2018 2:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Low emission shuttle bus among greener glens ideas
story: THE development of a low-emission shuttle bus service between Inverness and Drumnadrochit are among the suggestions put forward in community-devised local energy plan.The document, which will be launched at a Green Living Day in Drumnadrochit on Saturday, also includes proposals such as the development of a community-owned solar array and the provision of advice around tarf switching.The plan, which outlines key priorities for the Drumnadrochit area in relation to energy saving, power and heat generation and transport, has been drawn up following consultation with residents and ious organisations.It has been funded with EU and Scottish Government money and its development has been led by a steering group including environmental charity, Soirbheas, Glen Urquhart Rural Community Association, the Chamber of Commerce and Glen Urquhart Community Coouncil.The launch will be among a range of activities during the Green Living Day which aims to help local residents save money, have warmer homes and be healthier.Visitors will have the chance to try an electric bike, enjoy a taster health walk or join in a children' clothing and book swap.There will also be a Dr Bike session organised in conjunction with Velocity Cafe for visitors to take their cycles for a health check and simple maintenanceHome Energy Scotland will provide advice on energy saving and there will be a display of art work created by primary school pupils on the theme of green superheroes.It will be held at Glen Urquhart Hall between 11am and 3pm.Another event, Hard To Treat Properties, will be held at the Craigmonie Centre on Wednesday October 3 from 7pm to 9pm.Moses Jenkins of Historic Environment Scotland will share his expertise on installing dferent types of insulation, glazing, draught-proofing as well as outlining other energy-saving measures.Home Energy Scotland and Resource Efficient Scotland specialists will be on hand to offer free, impartial energy efficiency advice and provide information on the latest sources of funding support.- More information can be obtained on www.soirbheas.org/green-living-eventSunday 30 Sep 2018 2:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Pensioner pleads for help with poorly cat
story: &nbspAn Inverness pensioner is appealing for help with her cat' medical treatment after discovering that her monthly pet plan does not cover the cost of an X-ray.Marie MacIver' five-year-old cat Charlie has a painful leg and needs the scan to determine what treatment can be given.However, Mrs MacIver, who relies on disability benefit, is unable to afford the X-ray, which will cost about &pound300.She has now contacted the&nbspmedia in a plea for kind-hearted Invernessians to come forward."There is no way I can afford to pay for the X-ray," she said."Since it' very dficult for me to get out, I have already had to pay for the vet to come to the house and give Charlie a medical, as well as a bottle of anti-inflammatories which cost &pound29 and did nothing."I already pay &pound10 a month for a pet plan but it doesn&rsquot seem to cover anything."I have tried everywhere to get help with the vet' bills &ndash the PDSA, RSPCA and Cats Protection, but I haven&rsquot been able to get help from anywhere."I hate to see him in pain and I think it' getting worse."It came out of the blue about a month ago, and now it is just not going away."Mrs MacIver lives alone with Charlie and says she has a special bond with her little cat."He' my companion and is often the only company I have," she said."He sleeps on my bed and follows me into the kitchen, and he seems to know not to stray too far from the house because I need him."He' really more like a dog than a cat."I try my best to take care of him but things like this are very dficult, and it is such a shame because he is a lovely little cat."I need to help Charlie get better."&nbspCan you help Mrs MacIver with the cost of Charlie' X-ray? Email us via newsdesk@spp-groupSunday 30 Sep 2018 2:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Response to Charlie tale stuns cat owner
story: &nbsp&nbspMarie MacIver, who lives in Hilton and relies on disability benefit, lives alone with her five-year-old cat Charlie.She got in touch with the Courier after it became apparent that Charlie' injured leg needed an X-ray, which she could not afford.She had already contacted animal welfare charities without success.After we printed the story last week, we were inundated with offers of help for little Charlie &ndash and Mrs MacIver admitted she was moved to tears.&ldquoI don&rsquot know what I would have done without everyone who offered to help, she said.&ldquoI&rsquove been in tears because people have been so nice. I had a card from a lady wishing me and Charlie all the best. That was such a touching thing for someone to do.&ldquoThe card has pride of place on my mantelpiece.&ldquoPeople are just so kind, even to a poor little animal like Charlie.&ldquoSome people would see him as just a cat but to me he is much more than that.&ldquoI just want to say thank you so much to everyone who has been in touch wanting to help. I didn&rsquot think anything would come of it.Local cat owner Ian Aird came to Mrs MacIver' aid, donating enough money to cover the cost of the X-ray, leaving her gobsmacked.&ldquoI can&rsquot thank Ian enough, she said.&ldquoIt was so kind of him to do that for me and Charlie.&ldquoI&rsquom so incredibly grateful to Ian. I have no words that can describe how grateful I am for what he has done.Mr Aird said: &ldquoI am a cat owner myself and when I read the story I felt so much sympathy for Mrs MacIver.&ldquoShe is an elderly lady and she doesn&rsquot get out of the house very much so that' why I thought it was important that I helped her.&ldquoFor someone in her position, Charlie is often her only companion.&ldquoThis situation seems to have resonated with a lot of people, particularly cat owners around Inverness.Charlie has now been diagnosed with patellar dysplasia, where the kneecap is slightly misshapen, and requires no further treatment other than keeping weight off his leg.&ldquoI&rsquom so relieved it' nothing serious, Mrs MacIver added.&ldquoBut I have taken out an insurance plan, and I would encourage everyone else to do the same in case something like this happens again.Sunday 30 Sep 2018 2:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Star honour for city cadet
story: &nbsp&nbspEuan Stewart from 1st Battalion the Highlanders&rsquo Inverness detachment has been appointed the battalion' new Cadet Regimental Sergeant Major .The 17-year-old who joined the youth organisation five years ago is being championed for his long list of achievements.Graeme Wells from the army cadet force said the high flying cadet has climbed right up the ranks to completed his Master Cadet, which is the highest a cadet can reach.On top of his cadet achievements he has also had the honour of being the Lord Lieutenant' Cadet of Inverness-shire.This position allowed him to assist the Lord Lieutenant of Inverness-shire, Donald Cameron of Lochiel, in his duties as Her Majesty The Queen' appointed representative for the area.Mr Wells said Mr Stewart was also an &ldquoexcellent shooter who has represented the battalion on several occasions in regional and national shooting competitions, including the Inter-Service Cadet Rle meeting at Bisley Ranges in Surrey.Last year he scooped the battalion its first trophy in this contest, coming in first in the Patriotic 500 competition.Mr Wells added: &ldquoEuan was promoted to his new position at Fort George last Saturday while taking part in training for the upcoming Scottish Cadet Military Skills Competition in which he has been named as the team' Section Commander.Mr Stewart, who is a Culloden Academy pupil and has his heart set on studying mechanical engineering at university, said he was delighted with the honour.He said: &ldquoMy brother Andrew was originally in the cadets and he achieved a high level so that inspired me and we also have connections with the Honorary Colonel Councillor Carolyn Caddick whose son was the last RSM so and I guess I was quite inspired by him too.Sunday 30 Sep 2018 2:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: World of work goes back to school in Inverness
story: &nbsp&nbspThe event &ndash which was supported by Highlands and Islands Airport Limited , Skills Development Scotland and Developing the Young Workforce  Inverness &amp Central Highland &ndash involved organisations across a wide range of sectors, including healthcare, education, construction, hospitality, tourism, science and technology, finance, creative industries and emergency services..The pupils also had the chance to work on their CVs, discover workplace expectations and practice their interview skills.Head teacher John Rutter said: &ldquoWe consistently have high positive destination figures for our school leavers and events such as this really complement the year-round hard work that all our staff put into giving our young people the best possible chances for success.For the first time, the event also included a mini trade show, giving pupils the chance to mingle with the more than 40 businesses attending.Andy Maxtone, programme manager for DYW Inverness &amp Central Highland, said: &ldquoInitiatives like the employability event are great for pupils, as it opens their eyes to the dferent types of jobs out there, and the ious paths that can be taken to attain them.Sunday 30 Sep 2018 2:36 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: aberdeen edged out 1 0 by celtic at parkhead
story: Aberdeen failed to secure back to back wins at Parkhead for the first time since 2004 as they lost 1-0 to Celtic.The Dons faced Celtic bidding to rack up another away win over the defending Premiership champions having triumphed 1-0 at Parkhead in the final game of last season.The pressure was on Celtic boss Brendan Rodgers following the defending champions worst start to a league campaign in 20 years.However the Hoops grabbed the three points courtesy of an improvised back-heeled goal from substitute Scott Sinclair in the second half.Aberdeen made two changes to the side which edged past Hibs 6-5 on penalties in a draining League Cup quarter-final clash at Easter Road on Tuesday evening.Striker Stevie May ed to the starting line up with Sam Cosgrove dropping to the bench.Northern International winger Niall McGinn also ed ahead of loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe.Celtic created the first opportunity in the second minute following a swt passing move that culminated in a  Mikael Lustig cut back to James Forrest but the Scotland cap&#8217ss curling 15 yard shot flashed wide.The Dons threatened on the quarter hour mark when a corner kick swung in from the left was cleared as far as Gary Mackay-Steven at the edge of the box but the winger sliced his shot well wide.It was a cautious start from both sides who were showing mutual respect.Mackay-Steven was becoming increasingly influential on the left flank and burst down the wing in the 19th minute before crossing towards the far edge of the penalty area.McGinn raced in to meet Mackay-Steven&#8217s delivery but  drilled a powerful 20 yard drive just wide.Moments later McGinn crossed into the box and it just agonisingly alluded the unmarked James Wilson eight yards in front of goal.Celtic were denied by the woodwork in the 25th minute when a curling effort from Odsonne Edouard from 25 yards beat ing keeper Joe Lewis only to crack off the far post.Aberdeen came close with a superb attack when Mackay-Steven drove at goal and stepped past two challenges inside the penalty box to open up a shooting opportunity.Keeper Craig Gordon somehow pushed it behind.From the resultant corner Andy Considine, who netted in the 1-0 win in May, rose to power in a header that beat Gordon but Leigh Grfiths was on the line to kick clear.In the 48th minute Dons keeper Lewis pushed a low drive from Callum McGregor wide for a corner.On loan Manchester United striker James Wilson fired in a superb 25 yard curling effort from the right only to be denied by Gordon&#8217s ing save in the 52nd minute.Wilson was to come off on the hour mark to be replaced by Sam Cosgrove.Celtic went ahead in the 63rd minute when a ball from James Forrest into the box took a deflection that sent it spinning up into the box.Substitute Scott SINCLAIR used real improvisation and awareness to back-heel the ball into the net from six yards.It came at a time when Celtic were becoming increasingly frustrated and Aberdeen influential.In the 73rd minute Grfiths&#8217 shot a free-kick wide of the defensive wall but keeper Lewis got down to block.The Dons should have equalized in the 75th minute when Mackay-Steven whipped in an intelligent free-kick towards the onrushing Mikey Devlin but with the goal beckoning the defender volleyed it wide.Deep into injury time Grfiths broke upfield and clearly pulled on the jersey of Devlin to gain an advantage. The referee waved play on and Grfiths raced upfield only to miss when chipping over the advancing Lewis.Aberdeen: Lewis, Logan, Shinnie, Considine, McKenna, Wilson, McGinn, Mackay-Steven, May, Devlin, Ball.Subs: Cosgrove , Lowe , Anderson Subs not used: Cerny, Forrester, Gleeson, Campbell.Celtic: Gordon, Hendry, Brown, Grfiths, Boyata, Ntcham, Edouard, Lustig, McGregor, Forrest, Tierney.Subs: Sinclair , Rogic , Morgan .Subs not used: Bain,  Gamboa,  Christie,  Mulumbu.Referee: Bobby Madden

title: boss has no worries over logan at celtic
story: Aberdeen Dons boss Derek McInnes today insisted he has no concern about Shay Logan’s  to Parkhead.Defender Logan will today face Celtic for the first time since he was red carded following full-time of the Dons’ 1-0 win at Parkhead in the final game of last season.During his celebrations at the end of the Reds’ first league win at Parkhead since 2004, the 30-year-old clashed with Mikael Lustig and Dedryck Boyata before being shown the red by referee Craig Thomson.Right-back Logan was hit with a two-game suspension which the Dons failed to over-turn on appeal.Earlier this season, Logan alleged he was the subject of racist abuse from CelticMcInnes said: “Shay is not worried about it so I am not worried about it. Shay will be fine. He is quite unique in that he doesn’t let things bother him too much.“I felt what happened that day was all blown out of proportion and really unfair on Shay and he got a two-game suspension for that. We felt it was unfair at the time but we move on.”Logan missed the first three games of the domestic season as the two-game ban for the red card was added to a one-game suspension that had carried over from the previous season.The incident came four years after Logan was the victim of racial abuse by former Celtic winger Aleksandar Tonev during a 2-1 loss in September 2014.Tonev, on loan from Aston Villa at the time, was hit with a seven-game ban by the SFA after being found guilty of the charge.Logan is set to start at Parkhead today as the Reds bid for back-to-back league victories at Celtic having secured that win at the end of last season.Meanwhile, McInnes has ruled out any move for former Manchester City and Aston Villa attacking midfielder Stephen Ireland.The 32-year-old had been strongly linked with Aberdeen in recent days. Although the transfer window has closed Ireland is available to sign for a club as he is a free agent having left Stoke City during the summer.He had trained with Bolton during the summer and was also a target for a number of German Bundesliga clubs.But McInnes insists there was never any chance of a swoop for the former Republic of Ireland international who has racked up more than 250 appearances in the English top flight.The Dons gaffer also insisted there will be no fresh additions to his squad before the winter transfer window opens on January 1.He said: “He  is a friend of Shay’s and it was really just a conversation with Shay.“There is nothing in that but it has grown arms and legs the last couple of days. I am happy with the squad and we need to get players back from injury as well“The squad is what it is and I am not looking to add to it. Hopefully we will get one or two back from injury over the next few weeks.“We have a few who are on the cusp of coming back and a few longer term.”McInnes has six players ruled out of today’s trip to Parkhead – Lewis Ferguson , Scott Wright , Frank Ross , Tommie Hoban , Mark Reynolds  and Greg Tansey .McInnes said: “Lewis is still out but will be back next week .“There are a couple of bumps and bruises from the other night at Hibs but nothing that will keep anybody out.“Niall McGinn’s groin has responded well. He had treatment with the physios and trained yesterday so will travel.“Frank Ross unfortunately had a wee reaction to training on Monday and travelling to the game. We will get his back looked at more closely.“Tommie Hoban got his operation on Wednesday. It is a three-month timescale so we are looking at December being a bit more active for him.“In terms of ing to play for Tommie it will be January.”On-loan Manchester United striker James Wilson, who recently ed from a hamstring problem, is set to start today for the third game in succession.McInnes said: “James surprised us all with being able to last so long “We had a plan of two 60 minutes and then see how he felt going into Celtic.“James showed real determination and played his part in helping to get the result.“I have been delighted with James.”

title: sign our petition to change time of aberdeen semi final clash at hampden3
story: Dons fans have branded the decision to make Aberdeen’s League Cup semi-final against Rangers at Hampden a noon kick-off “an absolute disgrace”.Supporters’ groups, the club and Hearts have all hit out after it was revealed both semi-finals would be played at the national stadium in Glasgow on the same day.And now the Evening Express has launched a petition in an effort to make the SPFL reconsider the ridiculous scheduling of the Aberdeen v Rangers League Cup semi-final on Sunday October 28.The lunchtime kick-off is an outrageous time for fans from the north-east to get to Hampden – and scheduling the Hearts v Celtic semi on the same day at the same venue only compounds the problem.Sign this petition to send a message to the SPFL that’s loud and clear: This showpiece fixture MUST be changed to a new venue or time for the sake of the fans.
